Symbols of Safety

Schools, Hospitals and Public Institutions should be equipped with approved fire escapes. Neglect of this important matter may result in terrible tragedy. Investigate the WESTeel Potter Tubular Fire Escape, the only fire escape approved by National Board of Fire Underwriters.

The WESTeel Potter Fire Escape has actually saved hundreds of lives. (See inside pages).

WESTeel Potter Fire Escapes are Made in Canada
Here are proofs of the value of WESTEEL Potter Fire Escapes

200 CHILDREN SAVED

Illustration at left shows the burning of the Harrah Public School. 200 children on the second story got out of the burning building through the tubular fire escape. No panic, no loss of life—not one of them received a scratch.

HOSPITAL PATIENTS SLIDE TO SAFETY ON THEIR MATTRESSES

24 patients of the Lutheran Hospital, Bemidji, Minnesota, were safely removed on their mattresses through the tubular fire escape. Not one of the patients suffered any ill effect. The outside temperature was over 30 degrees below zero when this fire occurred.

80 CHILDREN ESCAPE

The school building shown at left was entirely gutted by fire. 80 children escaped from the burning building through the tubular fire escape without injury.

Illustration below shows the installation of a WESTEEL fire escape on a hospital building. At the left of the photograph is shown the ruins of the old hospital building destroyed by fire from which about 25 bedridden patients were removed in the nick of time to avert a horrible death. After this experience in removing patients with a slide escape the authorities were convinced that the tubular fire escape method of removing bedridden patients is the best and most practical.

WESTEEL Potter Fire Escapes are Made in Canada
Give the people in your care a chance for their lives

A very heavy responsibility rests upon those whose duty it is to provide proper fire escape equipment for schools, hospitals and public institutions.

ARE YOUR SCHOOLS SAFE?

Fire records show that panic has been the cause of great loss of life in school fires. Every building can be made perfectly safe by the installation of WESIEEL Potter Fire Escapes.

INSIST ON PROPER EQUIPMENT

Safe Orderly Exit
No Panic - No Loss of Life

Fire has no mercy for helpless patients

Weak, bedridden hospital patients, the aged and infirm, should have every facility provided for quick escape in the case of fire. Experience has shown that the ordinary type of fire escape is useless where helpless people are concerned. WESIEEL Potter Tubular Fire Escapes (hospital type) are built large enough to accommodate a patient on the regular hospital mattress. Patient on mattress can be carried to the tube and removed in safety. Two persons on the ground below take care of the patients as they arrive at the end of the fire escape. This method is quick, safe and does not injure the patient in any way.

Equip Your Buildings with
WESIEEL POTTER FIRE ESCAPES

The WESIEEL Potter Tubular is the only fire escape of any kind approved by the Underwriters' Laboratories for use on hospitals.
Widespread Approval of WESTEEL Potter Fire Escapes

Fire Chiefs of Canada in Annual Convention at Shawinigan Falls, Quebec, 1931, passed a resolution approving the WESTEEL Potter Fire Escape. Provincial Fire Marshals and Public Officials all over Canada have endorsed this modern escape.

WESTEEL Potter Fire Escapes on a building are recognized as symbols of safety. We have on file hundreds of letters which testify very strongly in favor of this modern safe exit.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo addressed to Mr. Christianson with reference to the erection of new fire escapes at the Wabasca R.C. Indian Residential School.

I note from your letter that you already have fire escapes and every effort should be made to keep these in as good condition as possible. As you are aware an allowance is made for a night watchman and the Department will depend on you to employ a competent man for this very important work.

No funds are available in the current year's appropriation for the expenditure that would be required to supply the new fire escapes recommended in your letter and under these circumstances favourable consideration cannot be given to your request at the present time.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. L. Beuglet, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Wabasca R.C. Indian Residential School,
Desmarais, Alta.
November 30th 1938

Mr. M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Agencies,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Last Summer I have had the chimneys of the Wabasca R.C. Indian Res. School demolished and new ones made by a competent bricklayer. By so doing I think that I have somewhat minimized fire hazard to life.

There still remains to improve fire escape facilities. At present, there are wooden stairs at each end of the School from the top floor to the ground with exits from each storey; fire drills are being practised via these stairs very often but the building being high and consequently the stairs long, the building, in my opinion, can not be evacuated as quickly as one would wish.

To facilitate quicker evacuation of the building, I thought that the installation of a tubular galvanized iron fire escape on each side of the building with exit from the dormitories which would run directly to the ground would greatly reduce the danger of loss of life by fire.

While in Edmonton, I called at the Western Steel Products Corporation Limited and asked these people to quote the price on the installation of two fire escapes and I am enclosing the manager's letter as well as a circular illustrating the fire escapes which I wish to have installed at our School.

It is my constant endeavour to improve the equipment for fire protection of the Wabasca R.C. Indian Res. School and, in my opinion, our fire protection will not be adequate until fire escapes of the type referred to are installed.

You will please give this matter your kind attention.

I remain,
yours very truly,

L. Beuglet, a.m.j.
Principal,
Wabasca R.C. Indian Res. School,
Desmarais P.O. Alberta.
EDMONTON,

November 30th, 1938.

Rev. L. Beuglet, C.M.I.,
O/c Oblate Fathers,
EDMONTON, Alberta.

Reverend Father;

Following interview in our office yesterday relative to a tubular fire escape for your Mission at Wabasca.

We are attaching hereto a circular illustrating our "WABASCA" Potter Fire Escapes which we manufacture in our Edmonton factory.

This fire escape is of a special manufacture and is the only fire escape approved by the National Board of Fire Underwriters, coupled to the fact that Fire Chiefs, Provincial Fire Marshalls and Public Officials all over Canada have endorsed this modern fire escape. Please note on the back page of the enclosed circular the installations which we have made all over Canada.

At your Wabasca Mission where you have the custody of hundreds of children the question of fire protection is no doubt one that is of all importance to you and to all those who are responsible for your institution. We are confident that with the erection of a Potter Tubular Fire escape you will have solved your fire protection problem. We call your attention to the method of operation which becomes a pleasure to the children using the fire escape.

For school installation we supply a tubular escape "3" in diameter. We will supply and install the two tubular fire escape on your building which will be approximately sixty-six feet long with a height of about 36' from the floor of the upper story to the ground. We to supply the entrance doors, bolts, hardware, supports, concrete bases etc.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Please find enclosed a list of the material to be bought for a combined carpenter & blacksmith shop at the Wabasca R.C. Indian Resid. School.

I take as granted the request of such a building presented to the Department last November through Rev. F. Plourde, O.M.I.

I would appreciate the material being delivered at Slave Lake, Alta., during the month of February in order to have it hauled to Wabasca on winter roads. (As you know, hauling is impossible in summer.)

Thanking you in advance for the attention you will give to this matter, I remain, Dear Sir,

Yours very truly,

F. S. Lajoie, O.M.I.,
Grouard, Alta.

N.B. Would you need additional information, please refer to me at 600, Cumberland Street, Ottawa, where I'll be for some time.

Edmonton, Alta.
Dec 6th 1939.

Dear Mr. L'Heureux,

Enclosed herewith invoice for school material which I ordered at the beginning of the school term. These were needed badly to begin the school with and could not wait till winter at which time our freight is brought from Slave Lake. Will you kindly recommend payment of same.

I understand that Father Floch, acting Principal, has advised you that Madeleine Bigstone has not returned to school. This is quite correct. She is being detained by Chief Bigstone. Will you kindly take the
necessary steps to have this girl returned to school. Please advise Father Floch what is to be done regarding this girl, as I am on my way to Ontario. I will stop over at Calgary to say hello to Mr. Schmidt and will then proceed to Ottawa where I will meet Bishop Langlois. It is possible that I will call at the Department of Indian Affairs and shake hands with the "Okimawok" at Ottawa and will give them your regards.

Boujou

L. Beuglet

Oct. 12th, 1938.

Reverend Father S. Lejeune, O.M.I.,
Croward, Alta.

Dear Father,

It has been my constant endeavour to improve the equipment for fire protection of the Wabasca R.C. Indian School; hand fire extinguishers have been placed at strategic places of the school, but I think that those extinguishers are not in sufficient number and I am asking you to have a few more forwarded to us. During Summer we have had the chimneys demolished and new ones have been made with flue lining by a competent bricklayer. By so doing, we believe that we have greatly minimized fire hazard to life.

There still remains to improve fire escape facilities. At present, there are wooden stairs at each end of the School from the top floor to the ground with exits from each storey; fire drills are being practised via these stairs very often, but the building being high and consequently the stairs long, the building, in our opinion, can not be evacuated as quickly as one would wish.

To facilitate quicker evacuation of the building, I would suggest that a tubular galvanized iron fire escape be installed on each side of the building with exit from a window of each dormitory, which tubular escapes would run directly to the ground and would be supported by braces along the rear part of the building.

Enclosed herewith a photograph of the Wabasca R.C. Indian School on which I have traced in ink where these tubular fire escapes could be most advantageously installed; from the dimensions of the buildings given, an expert in this matter will be able to judge amount of tubing required.

I believe that the danger of loss of life by fire would be greatly reduced, if these tubular fire escapes were installed.

Would you then kindly bring this matter to the attention of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Mr. R.A. Hoey, Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Dear Mr. Hoey,

When Rev. F. Heuglet came to Grouard lately, I discussed with him the question of the water system at the Wabasca R.C. Indian School. The Principal is of the opinion that it is not necessary to send an Engineer to Wabasca, for they are not confronted with the same difficulties there as it was the case for other schools of the Vicariate.

At Wabasca, there is no question of drilling a well. The school is located close to the lake where an abundance of good water is available at a short distance of the shore at all times. The Rev. Father Principal explained that all that is necessary to do is to install a sheltered pump at the shore of the lake which would pump the water from the lake and force same into a pressure tank which has already been installed in the basement of the School and which has a capacity of 1000 gallons.

A few years ago, a small automatic electric pump had been installed close to the pressure tank inside the school which pumped directly from the lake and forced the water into the pressure tank successfully, but in recent years, the level of the lake lowered and the water pipe had to be extended further into the lake. Of this action, resulted a considerable reduction of the capacity of the pump.

If a more powerful pump was secured and installed at the lake shore instead of being placed close to the pressure tank inside of the school and a 50 feet crib built into the lake to protect the water pipe from frost, this would solve the problem of the water shortage at Wabasca.

The crib suggested could be built in September when, as a rule, the lake is at the lowest point. Any direction given will be followed.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Re: Set of Batteries for
Wabasca R.C. Ind. School.
Answering yours of Dec. 18th, I beg
to state that a large set of batteries has been applied for
at the advice of experienced men in electricity. The heavier
the batteries, the cheaper the service.

I admit that the present batteries have
not lasted very long, about six years. To appreciate the
service they have given, we have to keep in mind that the
line has been extended to most of the buildings where arti-
ficial light is needed: cow-barn, chicken-coop, shops, etc.
The authorities have thought advisable to do so to minimize
to the limit the danger of fire. There is no proof-fire
building at Wabasca. Would the fire start anywhere when it
winds, that it could sweep all the buildings in a few hours.
Experience has proved that the best protection against fire
is safety.

May I point out that the winter days are
far shorter in the North than in the South. For three months,
there is but a few hours of daylight. It requires more arti-
ficial light.

As to the lighting of the Hospital, ____
St-Martin's Hospital, not St-Theresa's as written previous-
ly ___ the service is not given free. The Mission is indem-
nized for the service. In fact, the Hospital is not charging
for the hospitalization of the children of the School when
they need nursing. It means an appreciable service.
I have no objection to a lighter set of batteries. The essential is to get one, the old one being run down. A keen study of the question has convinced me that on the long run we are better to get heavy batteries. Transportation cost is about the same and the service is better. Transportation of batteries to Wabasca is so serious a problem that I am aiming to reduce this work as much as possible. There is no summer road to Wabasca and batteries can not stand very temperature. It is why I have requested you to have the batteries shipped in the beginning of March when very severe weather is exceptional.

The firm getting the deal could be requested to take the old jars. An allowance of seventy five cents a piece is generally given for these jars. On 50 jars it would reduce the price of the new set by $42.00.

Please request the firm supplying the batteries the five copies of the bill to Grouard to be receipted. The batteries having to be shipped only in March, the invoices will not be back for the 1st of April if they are directed to Desmarais, Alta.

Let me profit by the coming of a new year to thank you, Mr. Hoey, for the interest you pay to our problems. Your last letter proves to what extend you are devoting your energies to the cause you are working for. Be sure of my most complete cooperation.

With the best wishes of the season, I remain,

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Yours very truly,

F. S. LaJoie, O.M.I.,
Grouard, Alta.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Answering yours of December 11th, I beg to state that I was not aware of the fact that a part of the allotment for the Wabasca R.C. School had been spent by the Department for equipment and extinguishers. Otherwise, I would not have presented the account for $592.15.

While what you propose to square the difference could be done, I take the liberty of making another suggestion. I have withdrawn a sheet showing wages of $66.95 which is pretty close to the balance submitted. I am making the correction required to coincide as closely as possible to what is left. Should the Department agree to pay the amount submitted, $81.75, the account of Wabasca would be closed for the fiscal year 1941-42.

May I ask you to submit what has been paid for the other schools as I cannot draft an accurate account before knowing this.

Let me point out that I had understood that the Department was to supply athletic and Manual Training equipment as well as fire extinguishers through a special fund allotted for these purposes. This will affect our finances. Though the amount is not considerable, when one has difficulty in balancing the budget, every dollar counts. It is to be hoped that the Department will find its way clear to assist the Schools facing the situation caused by the increase in the cost of living.

I was accused of pessimism two years ago when I stated that our expenses would be increased by 12% to 15% within a year or two. I was far from expecting that the revenue would be decreased by 7.76%. As a matter of fact, our revenue has diminished by approximately 22%. In view of the crop failure, financing is a serious problem for us. We trust that the Department will realize that the situation has to be remedied in some way.
I take this opportunity to thank you for what you are doing for our schools.

With the Compliments of the Season, I remain, Dear Mr. Phelan,

Yours truly,
Father S. Lajoie, O.M.I.,

Gentlemen:

Answering yours of March 17, your file No. 131-9-5, and to the attention of R. A. Hoey.

The reason we were obliged to supply a slightly used half horse power, 110 volt direct current motor with the washing machine shipped to the Indian School at W. house, was because no brand new, half horse power motor, 110 volt direct current was available at the time and we could get no assurance as to any possible delivery date. However, before we supplied the motor which we did, we took it to the expert electricians of this city, namely the Electrical Industries and had the motor checked and tested in every possible manner. The motor did not require any repair parts whatever, because it has been only slightly used, and therefore it was shipped out with the same guarantee mechanically, as a new motor.

Kindly note that this motor was not supplied by the manufacturers in Winnipeg of the washing machine. The motor specified of course was 110 volt direct current, and the manufacturers stated that the proper motor to operate their machine was a half horse power, and as we had that in stock and as the manufacturers of the washer advised us that it would be many weeks before they could secure a half horse power motor of those specifications, we decided, rather than to keep your customer waiting to supply this motor, but before doing so we did what we have stated above. The motor had been used very little in a town where it was necessary to supply. First of all, a direct current motor until such time as the 60 cy system was installed and then the change was made and during which short time the motor was in use, no injury whatever was done to the motor.

over please

PLEASE ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO THE COMPANY AND NOT TO INDIVIDUALS
We think therefore that the Principal of the school made a mistake in sending back the motor without first taking the matter up with us to get this assurance, and possibly we made a mistake in not advising him at the time the motor was supplied. However, he returned the motor before getting in touch with us, and then he wired us not to ship any motor because he was coming to the city and would discuss the matter with us.

When he arrived, he expressed the preference for a 3/4 H.P. motor as he believed the 1/2 H.P. motor was hardly sufficient to operate the washer to capacity. This of course, was not in accordance with the specifications of the manufacturer. He said however, that they would gladly pay the difference between the cost of a 1/2 H.P. and a 3/4 H.P., if we could secure a 3/4 horse motor.

We immediately air mailed our factory at Fergus, Ontario, asking if they could supply a 3/4 H.P., 110 volt D.C. motor, and they replied that they did not have any in stock but had phoned the motor manufacturers who said they did have one and would hold it for three days, giving us an opportunity to order by wire if we decided to have it brought through. This we did and our understanding is that this 3/4 H.P. motor is now on the way to us and it will be forwarded to the Mission immediately on its arrival here.

We trust this information will be satisfactory and that everything will now be all right.

Yours truly,

BEATTY BROS. LIMITED.

Dear Sir:

I just received your letter dated March 26,
File no. 131-9-5, regarding the Power Washing Machine
you supplied to our school. -- It seems that there is
a great deal of misunderstanding in all that which I
would like to help clarifying.

You state in your letter:
1- "It is extremely difficult for the Depart-
ment to handle these purchases if Principals do not
state exactly what they require". -- In this very case
of ours, my requisition, I believe, was plain enough:
please refer to your Purchase Order no. 9908, file no.
15-20-1, dated the 14th of November 1941, which reads:
"One only Beatty Washing Machine, One Compartment,
Metal Cylinder Type, capacity 50 lbs. or 30 Bed Sheets
per load, equipped with 110 volt D.C. Motor". This
ALL METAL Machine is equipped with ½ H.P. Motor.

But you advised that during the war it was
not possible to supply us an ALL METAL Washer and then
the Department substituted the ALL METAL by a WOODEN
one; this was perfectly all right with me.

But apparently, the WOOD CYLINDER TYPE Washer
requires a ½ H.P. Motor to operate. As a question of
facts, the Motor shipped with the Washer could not
run the Machine properly: it was a used motor and
over-heating.

2- You stated also: "Once the order is placed
you have no authority to change it". -- I am very sorry
if I did interfere with your authority and please accept
my sincere apologies. When writing to Beatty Bros., my
sole intention was to tell them that the motor
shipped was not in proper order. And later when I met
Mr. Sterne, Mgr. in Edmonton I explained him (and he
admitted it) that ½ H.P. Motor was for a ALL METAL
Washer and not for a WOOD CYLINDER TYPE which appa-
rently wants more power.
There are the facts. Now I leave to you to see who should pay the difference between the two motors.... but I sincerely believe that I should not have to pay it from our own funds, as sufficient allocation have been provided for the Washing Machine and THE PROPER MOTOR to run it. Once more I do not ask for 1 H.P. or 3/4 H.P. Motor, but for the PROPER Motor to run the Washer that the Department have been good enough to grant us.

I did not yet recieve the motor; if I do receive it, before using it, still I will wait hearing from you, making sure that everything is clear.

I regret very much to give you all that trouble, but writting you I expect to help straighting up the matter.

Sincerely yours,

Rev. B. Rainville, O.M.I.

Extract from a letter to Mr. Neary, re requisitions for the residential schools in the Grand Diocese, signed by Rev. L. Beauglet, O.M.I. at McLennan, Alta., Sept. 13, 1948.

Re: Wabasca

Father Guimont called at the Bishop's House last night and explained that the floor of some of the rooms were in very bad condition and worn out, and required to be replaced. I believe that the sum of $1500.00 would cover the cost of replacing these floors and covering them with linoleum. I shall get in touch with the Principal and ask him to let me know the amount of flooring and the number of yards of linoleum required for the job, and shall give you this information as soon as it is available. If you will arrange to have the sum of $1500.00 available for these repairs, I believe that it would cover this expenditure. I understand that the flooring could be obtained locally at Wabasca but the linoleum would have to be secured by your purchasing branch.

I believe, Mr. Neary, that the above requisitions are legitimate and trust that you will give them your very careful consideration.

(Sgd) Rev. L. Beauglet, O.M.I.

It is noted that the flooring can be obtained locally and you may obtain a quotation and advise us at what price the lumber can be secured and the name and address of the person from whom purchase can be made. We will then submit this request to our Purchasing Agent.

Bernard F. Neary

Reverend Sir:

In response to your request on refrigeration equipment for the residential Indian school at Wabasca, we have pleasure in quoting on the supply and installation of the refrigeration equipment, and also on the supply of the Fiberglas insulation and the necessary hardware and door gasket material.

You would require approximately 1266 Board feet of Fiberglas at a cost of $.685 per board foot, or a total of $88.61, this is assuming that the box will be 7' wide, 7' long and 7'6" high, inside measurements.

The pair of 12" hinges and a heavy duty latch and strike, together with 24' of door gasketing would cost $19.45.

The refrigeration equipment, plus the cost of installing it, with transportation included would cost $585.00, or a total of $693.06, bearing in mind that the Fiberglas insulation is an approximate figure but will be very close.

Due to the inaccessibility of Wabasca, we will, insofar as the guarantee is concerned, only guarantee to repair or replace any parts which prove to be defective within one year guarantee period, f.o.b. our warehouse, as it would be necessary for us to charge the transportation to Wabasca should service become necessary.

We would, in this regard, have this equipment installed by our most capable serviceman and would have him plan to stay on the job for a good period after the
equipment is put in operation, so that every possible means of checking the equipment would be done, avoiding as far as possible the necessity of a service trip for a number of years.

If this equipment meets with your approval we will appreciate very much your valued order.

Dear Sir,

With reference to Circular 150-40, I beg to advise you that the following are the names and register numbers of the children who are being kept in our school and who are over sixteen years of age:

Julie Beaver, age 22, register no. 061.

Veronique Gladu, .. 21, .. 063.

1) Julie Beaver, after being discharged at the age of sixteen, returned to school after the holidays, complaining that she was being ill-treated at home by her brothers; she also stated that her mother, being a needy widow, received a monthly ration from the district Indian agent, which ration was insufficient to support both herself and her mother; request was then made to the Department that she be permitted to remain at school, which request was granted to her; since then the girl has been staying at school engaged in household work. By her application at domestic science she sets a splendid example to the younger ones. For this reason, I earnestly request that the Indian Dept. permit her to remain at school until she gets married.

2) Veronique Gladu is a crippled and an orphan girl. Statement of William Auger, Wabasca, Alberta.

I, the undersigned of Wabasca, Alberta do solemnly declare that I belong to the Roman Catholic Church, married in the Roman Catholic Church, and all my children have been baptized in the Roman Catholic Church, including Mary Agnes who is at present at the St. John's Anglican Indian Residential School at Wabasca. It is my wish that all my children be brought up in the Roman Catholic Church.

Regarding my daughter, Mary Agnes, who is now at the Anglican School at Wabasca, she was put at that school without my permission during my absence in 1931. When we got married, it was our intention of putting all our children at the Catholic School.

In due time I protested against my daughter being accepted at the Anglican School but my wish was not heeded to.

The following is a copy of the letter which I forwarded to the Indian Agency at Driftpile, whereby I protested against my daughter, Marie Agnes, being accepted at The Anglican School; the letter is dated January 30, 1933.

"I, the undersigned, protest against the forced enrollment of my daughter at the English Mission.

My wife, Sophie Alock, had placed her therein for two months only. All my children are Catholics.

If my daughter, Marie Agnes, has been re-baptized at the English Mission, I was not aware of it and it is absolutely against my wish.

I ask you, then, that my child be taken out of the English Mission. We are married by the Catholic priest, and my wife, Sophie, promised me that our children would be brought up as Catholics."

Signed: William Auger.

Witness: Francis Auger.

On July 27th, 1935, I have asked the R.C.M.P. for protection against my wife taking the children away again and putting them at the Anglican School, as I reserve the right to look after my children and it is my wish that all my children be brought up in the Roman Catholic Church.

Sworn before me at Witnessed.

Wabasca, Alta., this 2nd day of August, A.D. 1935

Commissioner for Oaths.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 35K 128-100 of the 23rd instant, attached to which was a report from Constable S. L. Grayson of Kinuso detachment regarding an Indian by the name of Gambler, from Calling Lake, taking his two daughters from the R. C. School at Wabasca against the wishes of the Rev. Principal. As I understand it now, the road from Athabasca to Calling Lake is practically, if not altogether, impassible, as sometime ago I intended to go up to Calling Lake and was advised against going at that time. Besides, when the policeman arrived there Gambler might not be there, and if he were it would then be a matter of taking the children from there to Wabasca, which is a long distance, and no doubt the only means of transportation would be by boat.

There is a merchant at Calling Lake by the name of Jas. H. McIntosh with whom I have had considerable correspondence from time to time, and I am directing a letter to him today pointing out what Gambler did and asking him if the Indian is there, and if so, requesting him to advise Gambler to take his children back to Wabasca. Dear Doctor McGill:

Reluctant as I may be I must again bring to your attention another affidavit in the matter of the education of children at Wabasca, Alta.

I have told you many times and emphatically that the course initiated by the Department this year in accepting affidavits for the admission of children in different schools was a most disastrous one. My experience of 22 years with the Department vouches for such assertions. During the tenure of office of the Honorable Mr. Murphy I would not mention you a course followed by the Anglicans who would always call on the Minister in the face of any difficulty in order to obtain their point. I knew it was useless to discuss indefinitely such matters. I never agreed to the decisions and manner of acting of the Department. All I did was to protest against the manner of seeking admission for Catholic children in the Protestant school at Wabasca and the wholesale acception by the Department on the face of affidavits who in my estimation had and still have no value. I hope that Mr. Crerar, being a Presbyterian, will not be as popular with my Anglican friends and therefore the latter will not call on him for above matters. I have never treated such matters with Cabinet Ministers on account of their religion and I may say to the credit of the Honorable Charles Stewart, former Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, that he was never biased or prejudiced in his direction of Indian Education by his religious allegiance.

I repeat what I have said before. The Anglicans have practically no children in their schools which rightly belong to them. If you were investigating you would find the majority to be Catholic or of Catholic origin. Let them work where they have someone to look after without trying by all possible means to drive Catholic parents from sending their children to their own schools.

Please give immediate consideration to Mr. Yellowknee's request and act accordingly. The answer may be sent to me and Rev. Fr. Beuglet at Desmarais.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Bishop of Grouard.

Ottawa, March 30th, 1936.

Dear Bishop Guy,

I have your recent letter, enclosing applications and certificates of health for the admission of Augustin Stuart, Joseph Stuart, George Auger, Charlotte Houle, Paul Loonskin and Marie Anne St. Sauveur to the Wabasca R. C. Indian Residential School.

Am I correct in presuming that the father of Augustin and Joseph Stuart was a White man? If so, do you consider the Department would be justified in accepting these children as grant-earning pupils? You know that, when we assume responsibility for these children, we often are obliged to incur considerable expense in future years.

The others appear eligible but two of them, viz., George Auger and Marie Anne St. Sauveur, are only four and five years old, respectively. There seem to be reasons why these should be admitted but they are really rather young. Possibly, you might have a chance to discuss their cases again with Father Beuglet. The admission of Charlotte Houle and Paul Loonskin is approved.

These cases bring out what we have previously discussed, viz., the advisability of concentrating recruiting efforts on Treaty Indian children. I think you will agree that this is the correct policy as, then, no one could question their eligibility, whereas, when children whose fathers are White are accepted, there is always the possibility of future inquiries and other White parents considering that their children should be admitted.

I trust you reached home safely and found everything in good shape.

With kind personal regards,

Yours sincerely,

Rt. Rev. Joseph Guy, O.M.I.,
Bishop of Grouard,
Grouard, Alta.

Your Excellency,

With further reference to the applications for the admission of Augustin Stuart,
Joseph Stuart,
George Auger,
Marie Anne St. Sauveur,
to the above School, you will please explain to the Department Officials that William Stuart, father of Augustin and Joseph, although he had an English name, was not a White man, but a Cree Half-Breed, who lived the Indian mode of life at Wabasca; in fact, the man trapped all his life and talked but the Cree language; his Indian name was "Tchakikapao". Lately, a surviving sister of William Stuart showed a paper upon which the father of Augustin and Joseph had written, when on his dying bed, that it was his wish that she look after his children after his death. Thus, she was appointed guardian of these children; this woman, as well as her husband, belongs to the Wabasca Bigstone Band and is paid the Indian annuities; their treaty number is 107. When the academic year is over, Augustin and Joseph are to spend the holidays with their guardians. Therefore, all reasons militate in favor of these children being admitted as grant-earning pupils.

There still remains to discuss the cases of George Auger and Marie Anne St. Sauveur. As I have already explained, the guardian of George Auger is Marie Anne Beaver, ticket no. 79, of the Wabasca Bigstone Band. As the child was only four years old, it was not without great hesitation that the School staff decided to admit the child to School. Being aware of the fact that Marie Anne Beaver was in the last stage of Tuberculosis and little George being in danger of contamination, the school staff thought it advisable to admit the child to school without further delay, and the staff were earnestly entreated to do so by the guardian herself.

With regards to the case of Marie Anne St. Sauveur, she was brought to school along with her brother by her mother about a year ago; the admission of the boy has already been approved by the Department. When the mother, Adelaide Crow, no. 25, of the Wabasca Bigstone Band, brought the children to school for institutional care, she explained that her husband was crippled and helpless and that she was in great straits. Little Marie Anne is in the kindergarten, is doing well, and is quite happy; it goes without saying that the Department are rendering a helpful hand to the afflicted parents in providing shelter, food, and education to these poor children. The fact that Marie Anne's mother is the daughter of Martha Emily Capstair Crow, ticket no. 26, aged and nearly blind, headman of the Wabasca Bigstone Band, explains well enough that the parents are living the Indian mode of life and would justify the Department in accepting Marie Anne as a grant-earning pupil.

Re William Auger, Wabasca, Alberta.

The following is a copy of the statement of William Auger, of Wabasca, Alberta, which was witnessed by Constable Grayson, R.C.M.P., and sworn before Mr. George Arnold, Police Magistrate at Wabasca, Alberta, on the 27th day of July, 1935.

"I declare that I am a half breed and that I do not belong to Treaty. That I reserve the right to look after my children. During my absence my children were put at the Anglican School without my permission.

I belong to the Roman Catholic Church, married in the Roman Catholic Church, and all my children have been baptized in the Roman Catholic Church, including Mary Agnes who is at present at the Anglican School at Wabasca. It is my wish that my children be brought up in the Roman Catholic Church.

I never received money from the Indian Department for my children. When Mary Agnes, my daughter, who is now at the Anglican School, she was put at that school without my permission, during my absence in 1931. Afterwards my wife tried to take her out of school. When we got married, it was my wife's intention of putting any Agnes into the Roman Catholic School. My other children are not Treaty and I do not wish them to belong to Treaty. I am able to support all my children. During my absence my mother is unable or looking after my children. The R.C.M.P. have warned my wife and told her to behave herself and return to me and not misbehave herself anymore. I am taking her back.

I have asked for protection against my wife taking the children away again. I want my children educated and I will decide where they will be educated.

Signed William Auger.

Witness signed
Constable Grayson R.C.M.P.

Sworn before
(signed) George Arnold, Police Magistrate, Wabasca,
July 27th, 1935."
Statement of Alfred Auger (Beakoyous)
treaty number 321, a member of the
Bigstone Band, Wabasca, Alberta.

On September 10th, 1935, I declared before Mr. H. Gallagher, Commissioner for Oaths, that I belonged to the Roman Catholic Church, that I was married in the Roman Catholic Church and wished that all my children be brought up in the faith and according to the teachings of the Roman Catholic Faith.

I also declared that before my marriage, my wife, Christine Beaver (Nanimahoo) had put Marguerite Edith, her daughter, at the Wabasca C.E. Indian Residential School, even though she had been baptized in the Roman Catholic Church, as well as her daughter.

I then stated that as Christine Beaver (Nanimahoo) was now married to me, I became the legal father of Marguerite Edith, which ipso facto conferred upon me the right to direct the religious faith in which she was to be brought up.

Additionally, I expressed the wish that Marguerite Edith be transferred from the Wabasca C.E. Indian Res. School to the Wabasca R.C. Indian Res. School.

On October 31st, 1935, your file no. 131-8-10, the Department of Indian Affairs wrote to Mr. Agent L'Heureux in connection with this matter, asking him to interview Mrs. Christine Nanimahoo, who, it is said, has declared that she wanted her daughter, Marguerite Edith, to be educated under the auspices of the Church of England.

I then stated that I have the right to direct this child and as the right to direct the religious faith in which she shall be brought up belongs to me, according to a rule laid down by the Deputy Superintendent General who says that the father has the right to direct and regulate the religious faith in which his child shall be brought up, I do not see the reason why I should not have been consulted regarding this matter instead of my wife.

I then reiterate the wish that Marguerite Edith be given instruction at school at the Wabasca R.C. Indian Res. School, and would therefore appreciate that she be transferred from the Wabasca C.E. Indian Res. School to the Wabasca R.C. Indian Res. School. My wife joins with me in expressing the same wish and has also signed this affidavit with me.

Sworn before me at Wabasca, in the Province of Alberta, this 3rd day of October, A.D. 1936.

Commissioner for Oaths.

Monseigneur et bien-aimé Père,

Depuis leur retour de la retraite les frères Laurin et L'Heureux travaillent à la plomberie; attendu que la saison est déjà presque terminée, ils ne pourront faire qu'à l'intérieur de la maison cette année; le travail de l'extérieur, i.e., septic tank et "disposal field" devra être remis à l'an prochain; vous n'ignorez pas que tous les frères sont allés donner un coup de main à la construction de l'église du Père Fournier, c'est de qui a causé le délai de plomberie; il y avait aussi les foins à faire et les récoltes à recueillir, ce que l'on ne pouvait pas faire sans causer des difficultés à la mission; plusieurs des "lambiers" sont à battre l'avoine; il faut bien qu'ils y soient, car l'on ne peut pas confier ce travail à des enracinés seulement, car ils détérioreraient nos machines; en un mot, tous les travaux doivent être conduits ensemble; toutefois, je n'ai pas à me plaindre, tout va bien; l'on s'attend à avoir "la bumper crop"; l'on compte récolter environ 500 sacs d'avoine, ce qui représentera une bonne somme d'argent; quand l'on sait que l'année se vend $3.00-$4.15 sac au Wabasca, de sorte que le tracteur et la batteuse sont déjà bien payés; quand l'on pense qu'ailleurs les récoltes ont manqué, l'on a raison de remercier le Bon Dieu de nous traiter en enfants gâtés; c'est ce que fait aussi notre cher icaire apostolique.

A propos, attendu que l'on ne pourra terminer toute la plomberie cette année, que dois-je faire? vais-je vous embaucher quelques ouvriers achetez et le travail qui est à faire jusqu'ici, ou dois-je attendre jusqu'à ce que les travaux soient entièrement finis? ou bien encore, si l'octroi ne vaut que pour cette année, je puis vous faire approximativement les comptes pour tout le travail comme s'il était fini entièrement i.e., "septic tank et disposal field" compris. Il n'y aura pas d'inconvénient à attendre jusqu'à l'an prochain pour faire la "septic tank"; car l'on peut pour l'instant se servir de l'ancien système d'égout, et l'an prochain l'on complétera le travail.

Les bonnes sœurs se trouvent mieux avec leur nouvelle supérieure; tout le monde est à son aise; il y a gaîté, bonne humeur et entrain. Les 80 enfants sont entrés le jour de l'entrée même; c'est un record! il faut dire que j'avais promis de donner le sac de boîtes à chaque enfant qui entrerait à temps; étant au ministère, j'ai dit que s'il lui a fallu aller le chercher un à un et à l'aide de la police! quand il se serait contraint par le Département de lâcher ces mêmes enfants dont les parents ont signé des affidavits, il va bien être enragé. Je me demande souvent à quoi vont bien aboutir les affidavits que vous avez fait parvenir au Département; je serais de connaître le résultat de tous ces affidavits. Mr. McMillan doit bien être foucéré. A qui la faute? à moi-même? ou quoi qu'il en soit, n'oubliez pas ce qu'il vous diraisit daté du 2 avril 1935, quand il fit sortir 5 enfants de notre école pour les transférer à l'école protestante du Wabasca:

"Sworn affidavit were received from the

Caroline Auger, Marguerite Edith Nanimahoo,

Tous ces gens qui ont signé des affidavits persistent dans leur résolution de faire sortir leurs enfants de la mission anglaise; souvent ces gens viennent me demander si j'ai eu des nouvelles du département au sujet des affidavits qu'ils ont signés; il leur tarde naturellement de savoir à quoi vont aboutir leurs démarches. J'apprends à l'instant le décès de notre député, monsieur Giroux; grande perte pour nous; j'écrirais à sa femme pour lui offrir les sympathies et les prières de la communauté.

L'on m'annonce aussi à l'instant que les battages sont terminés. 500 sacs d'avoine, comme l'on pensait d'avoir achetée à l'extérieur, cette avoine livrée au Matane nous aurait coûté $1800. Cela paie de défricher!

Mais c'est assez de verbiage; merci de votre patience de m'avoir lu jusqu'à finir! Écrire, c'est bien, mais pouvoir se parler "by radiophones" ce serait encore mieux et surtout cela donnerait plus de satisfaction... quand l'on a besoin d'une pièce de rempage et qu'il doit attendre une réponse, pourquoi ne craindre pas l'heure ne venant pas le bonheur? Qu'on ait donné des explications "in black and white", il faut s'arrêter de patience, "sed in patientia vestra possidebitis animas vestras".

Tout le monde se porte bien physiquement et moralement... félicitons de loin ceux qui luttent à se dire vers le tout devoués à la cause des Indiens.

Bien à vous Mto et M.I.

P.S. Vous voudrez bien nous expédier par le fret de l'hiver prochain 350 livres de beurre; vous m'avez prié de vous avertir d'avance pour cette commande.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of the 19th instant, forwarding applications for the admission of three children of Joseph Bigstone to the Wabasca R. C. (St. Martin's) Indian Residential School, and enclosing a communication from the Principal regarding the reasons for taking these children into the school.

The Department will approve of the admission of Felix Bigstone, aged six years. It is noted, however, that Hilda and Rose are only four and two years of age respectively. The Department does not consider that it should be called upon to provide per capita grant for pupils of the age of these two girls and we are not prepared to approve of their admission. As it would involve hardship to send them home during the winter months, they may remain in the school until the end of June, next, when arrangements should be made to have this family brought together and Hilda and Rose returned to their care. Grant will be allowed for them from the date they entered the school until June 30th, next, only and the Principal may include their names on the quarterly returns until that date. You will be good enough to inform the Principal of the Department's decision regarding the return of these two girls to their parents in June, next, as no grant can be allowed for them after that date.

REPORT AND DIARY ON TRIP TO WABASCA FOR JANUARY 29th to February 2nd, 1937.

Stoney Point Reserve

While on the reserve I attended a meeting of Indians at the Councillor's House. A great dissatisfaction prevails among the Indians regarding J.B.Gambler's children, of Calling Lake, who have been stolen away from school by their parents. It was pointed out at the meeting that since the Gambler family was not compelled to respect the law and the school Principal, there would be several other families who would follow the same policy. Jean-Baptiste Gambler has threatened to shoot anybody interfering with his children. I would respectfully recommend that the Department give me authority to go and take the children back to school. At present we have planes stationed at Faust, only seven miles from the agency and I believe I could charter one for the round trip for approximately $100.00.

Headquarters:

(1) This family of treaty Indians live on a small reserve in the Calling Lake district. I.R.No.125, and has four children of school age at the present time.

(2) In January 1936 the parents brought two of their children, named Mary Ann and Helen Rose, to the Roman Catholic Indian residential school at Wabasca, where they were duly enrolled. At the end of April of the same year the parents returned to the school asking to see their children; after having visited with the children the parents stated that they were homesick for their children and wished to take them home. Father Boulet, the superior, explained to them that they could not be able to take the children back with them, upon which the parents simply picked up the children and walked off with them.

Sub-Division:

(3) Father Boulet called in Magistrate George Arnold, a special constable was apparently sworn in and the Father Mr. Gamble was brought up before the magistrate, where he simply told the magistrate and Father Boulet that he was not returning his children to school, and that it would be too bad for anyone attempting to take the children back, saying by words and signs that anyone attempting it would surely be shot; he apparently got away with this threat as nothing further was done and the children has been truant ever since.

Detachment:

(4) When the Indian Agent Mr. L'Heureux arrived in Wabasca to pay Treaty I interviewed him about this particular case, he informed me that the Indian Department has already paid $50.00 in holding these children back to the school. (Indian Dept. Kyle 5-119-British Isles Agency March 8th,) and I obtained a written notice to Mr. Gamble to have his children in school by Sept. 1st, 1936. (Duplicate of notice to Gamble attached hereto), this notice was delivered by me to Gamble on my way out from Wabasca, it was carefully explained to him by an interpreter, it was explained to him that he would have a charge placed against him for failure to comply to instructions, and the children conveyed to school.

ALPHONSE BEAVER,(Treaty Indian No.187)Moose Lake, Alta.
Parent of Truant Indian Children, Sec.10 Indian Act.

Headquarters
(i) The above named treaty Indian Alphonse Beaver is
the father of three children all of school age, as shown,
Joseph, Born Sept. 9th, 1923 Age 14
Henry, April 18th, 1927 IX
Martin, Aug. 7th, 1931 7

Sub-Division
the two children Joseph and Henry are duly enrolled
pupils of the St. Albert's Roman Catholic School at
Calling Lake, but did not attend school again
after being taken home to Calling Lake by their parents
last year; the superior of the school Father Bouglet has
on several occasions told the Indian to return the
children to school, but in the case of Gamble and
Wanakow, he has been threatened and told that the children
were not returning to school, they have now been truants
for a year.

Detachment
(2) When this man called at Wabasca for his Treaty Money
I warned this man in the presence of the Indian Agent,
that unless he saw to it that his children were at school
in proper time Sept. 1st, next, that a charge would be
preferred against him under the Indian Act, and the
children conveyed to school; I do not expect however that
this man will comply with these instructions.

P.C.R.
(3) This man and his family live at what is known as
Moose Lake (Fawcett Lake) about 30 miles North of Smith,
Alta., there is as I understand it a small settlement there
employed at fishing; this man belongs on reserve 183 at
Calling Lake.

A.R.V.No.
(4) Should it be necessary to convey these children to
school they would be conveyed the same time as the Indian
Child Mary Crow, grand-child of Wanakow (see separate
report of yesterday No.1-Francois (Wanakow) Cardinal --)
Calling Lake also.) The route I take, route being via way
of Smith-Slave Lake and then via mail-route to Wabasca, there
is a passable road in to Moose Lake.

Diary Date set for
(5) See remarks made by Indian Agent of Driftpile Agency
under file 35K 188-100 in connection with this Indian,
and his children.

(6) This fall another of his children becomes of school
age, which will make three children in all to go to school;
the child coming of age is Martin, who will be 7 years old
in Aug.

(7) Copy of this report for Indian Agent, Driftpile,
and Officer Commanding Peace River Sub-Div.

To,

Wanakew, Cardinal.
Calling Lake, Alta.

Sir,

I understand that the Indian child Sara Mary Crow, a girl 11 years old is living with your family; this girl is as you knew of school age and must attend school; she has now been absent from the St. Martins Indian Residential School for the last two years without reason.

This is to notify you that you are to insure this girl's attendance at the St. Martins Indian Residential School at Desmarais on the 1st of September next, failing which the girl will be escorted to school by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, and yourself liable to have a charge placed against you under Sec.10 of the Indian Act.

Yours Truly

Signed: N.P.L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

File References Re:
FRANCOIS,(WANAKOW), CARDINAL ------Moose Lake, Alta.
Grand Parent, Guardian of Indian Truant Child.
Sec. IO Indian Act.

Headquarters
(1) The above named Indian Francois Cardinal (wanakow),
is a Treaty Indian an up until lately used to live on the
Calling Lake Indian Reserve No.185, he is the Grand Father,
and the Guardian of the Indian child Sara Mary Crow, aged
11 years, this child has been a truant from the St.Martin's
Residential Indian School for the last Year.

Sub-Division
(2) This child left the School in June 1937 with her
Grand-Father Wanakow, and did not return at the beginning of
the school season Sept. Ist., during the Winter 1937-38 the
R.C.Father Rainville from the mission Wanakow and told him
to return the child to school, the father was told however
that no one was to take her back to school, and she has not
returned.

Detachment
(3) When attending the Indian Treaty Payments in
Wabasso this month I interviewed the Indian Agent Mr.E.F.
L'Heureux, who stated that he wants this child returned to
school this fall Sept. Ist., as I understand that the Indian
was living on the Calling Lake reserve I obtained a written
notice directed from the Agent to Francois Cardinal, with
instructions for him to return the girl to school, I find
however that this Indian has removed to a settlement on
Moose Lake (known as Smith Lake on map.) about 20 miles
North of Smith Lake, and I was therefore unable to serve the
notice on him, both Wanakow and Alphonse Beaver, another
Indian family, I understand are usually employed as fisher-
men at Moose Lake, there is a road in from Smith that can
be traveled by car as the fish is freighted on by truck,
and this Indian could be given his notice by driving in
from Smith.

P. C. R.
(4) Should it become necessary to return these children
to school from Moose Lake they would have to go in to
Wabasso from Slave Lake via the mail route, or they could
be returned to Calling Lake and then taken to Wabasso in
the aeroplane.

A. R. V. No.
(5) The Girl was Born Feb. 18th, 1927 and is now 11 years
old, she was taken out of school under the influence of
Jean Baptiste Gamble, near where they lived on the Calling
Lake reserve, see my report Re; Jean Baptiste Gamble ----
Calling Lake Alta., of even date, and the remarks by the
Indian Agent Mr.L'Heureux on file 35E-128-100.

Diary Date set for
(6) Copies for Indian Agent at Driftpile Agency, and the
Officer Commandant Peace River Sub-Div.
Original Notices for Wanakow attached hereto.

Sgt.

2. In the PM of Aug. 29th./38, patrol was made from Smith via Riped River to the Moose Lake Dist. (Pt. cute in game at Slave Lake undergoing repairs). Upon our arrival at Moose Lake, enquiries were made for the above, and I was informed that this man had moved his family, and was now living some 20 miles north east at Island Lake. Enquiries made revealed that the only means of getting to Island Lake was on feet, as a horse could not get thru the deadfall. I later learned that this man came to Moose Lake at the first of each month for his old Age Pension cheque, that Mr. Forsland was trusted for same. He stated that he would arrange the above mentioned. I came to Smith on Sept. 8th. and received his notice from the writer regarding the matter of getting the child into the school at Wahsenea. Patrol returned to Smith where we arrived at 7.45 PM of same date.

3. In speaking to the Indian Agent at Driftville re this matter, I informed him that up to the present time I had not been able to make any visits, but would do so on Sept. 16th. and he suggested that I advise this man that he would be given one week in which to get the child into the school, failing which action would be taken under the Indian Act. Further report will be submitted following service of notice on Sept. 8th, 1938. Extra copies attached.

Dear Sir:

Re: Alphonse Noskiye, register No. 111

With reference to the above named, I beg to advise that I have taken him back to school, although he was discharged in September. Having no record of the boy's age at the Mission, for I think that he was baptized at Little Red River, and believing that he was sixteen years of age, I discharged him in September. The boy now claims that he is only 14 years old and asked to be taken back to school.

This is the boy that was badly beaten by Elzear Ominayak, treaty number 111 Whitefish and against whom Constable Brown asked permission to prosecute.

This boy is a brother of Elzear Ominayak's wife; he was being brought up by his brother-in-law. The boy's ticket number is 335 Wabasca Band.

I believe that the boy's best place to stay is at school and I will keep him till he is sixteen, that is, until such time as he can earn his own livelihood, as he is being ill treated by his sister's husband.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) L. Beuglet, o.m.i.

Christianson then in charge of the Inspectorate, produced a Departmental ruling, possibly emanating from the Department of Justice, regarding parental ownership of illegitimate children and acknowledging our responsibility for the welfare of Adelaide St Sauveur and her children.

On September 2nd 1937, I received instructions from Mr. Inspector Schmidt, who had also investigated the case, to endeavour to place the children of this woman in a school as they became of age. The admission of Salomon St Sauveur is in keeping with these instructions.

Further investigation was made by Constable Brown, R.C.M.P. last January and as a consequence this woman has returned to her father on the Reserve and the man has left the district.

I am of opinion that these children should be accepted not only to school but be made treaty Indians, members of the Wabasca Band. The Band itself has no objection to this. The children are aged 7, 5 and 3.

Remarques prises aux archives de la Mission St. Martin, Desmarais Alberta.

Augustin Auger fils posthume de Paul Auger et de Joséphine L'Origane ou Letendre, élevé à notre école où il s'est attaché profondément à notre religion; ce qu'il a témoigné en amenant son premier-né pour être baptisé, bien que la mère protestante refusât de se marier catholique; en faisant baptiser son second dans les mêmes circonstances; refusant lui-même de suivre la femme voulant se marier devant le ministre, essayant de mettre son afin à notre école, "pour le suivre en sa foi", mais enfin cédant à l'obstination.

Pourtant celle-ci, témoin des soins donnés à son afin à l'hôpital avait déclaré vouloir le retirer de St. John pour nous le remettre; mais le ministre l'a gardé, a réussi à les marier et à baptiser le bébé, malgré les retards et oppositions du père qui enfin a fléchi.

Je ne sais si après ces remarques, qui ont été écrites par un Père, qui était l'ami d'Augustin Auger, montrent bien qu'il était protestant de cœur et de fait. Sa femme d'ailleurs a affirmé devant témoins que son mari s'est toujours récusé de la suivre à son église malgré toutes les instances qu'elle a faites auprès de lui.

Je redis donc que Augustin Auger a pu avoir une faiblesse, comme cela d'ailleurs est arrivé même à certains Saints, qui après s'être repris et repenti, ont versé leur sang pour la Foi; mais nul au monde qui a un peu d'esprit se permettra d'affirmer que ces Saints étaient des Protestants; peut-on l'affirmer d'Augustin Auger après ces remarques.

[Signature]

De plus, je puis affirmer que son épouse Gurty Marie Alok a abjuré la religion protestante, s'est fait baptisé dans la religion catholique, comme fait foi l'acte ci-inclus, et depuis lors pratique sa religion et s'approche sans honte des Sacrements.

Tous leurs enfants sont désormais baptisés dans la religion catholique, comme le fait foi les actes ci-inclus, à l'exception d'un seul qui en raison de son absence n'a pu être encore, mais qui sera présenté au prêtre catholique à la première occasion favorable.

Il est vrai que le plus âgé a été placé à l'école St. John du Wabasca, bien que baptisé catholique, en raison d'un moment de faiblesse, je le suppose; mais les parents le regrettent sincèrement.

Je crois que toutes ces explications sont plus que suffisantes pour approuver l'admission de Georges Russel à l'école St. Martin.

Avant de clore cette lettre, je tiens pourtant à faire remarquer que cette détermination à mettre cet enfant à notre école a été prise par les parents sans qu'aucune suggestion de notre part ait eu lieu; je puis en dire autant en ce qui regarde la décision du père à faire bénir son mariage et celle de la mettre à se faire admettre dans l'Eglise catholique.

Je vous donc, cher Monsieur, de me croire votre tout humble et tout respectueux.

Cher Monsieur,

Le Révérend Père L.Bouglet O.M.I. m'a prié en son absence de répondre à votre lettre du 16 février N.5-119. Voici donc ce que je crois devoir satisfaire à vos questions.

La raison principale, donnée par les parents au principal de l'école St. John, qui d'un air de mépris les accusait de le bafouer en mettant leur enfant à l'école catholique, est que leur enfant leur appartient et qu'ils ont le Droit de mettre leur enfant dans l'école de leur choix. En cela de fait, ils ne font que jouir du droit naturel de l'homme de disposer de ses enfants en matière d'éducation. Aussi ce droit des parents de choisir l'école de leurs enfants existe de temps immémorial, comme le confirment feu M.l'Honorable Lomer Gouin et M.l'Honorable Ernest Lapointe, tous deux Ministres de la Justice, dans leurs lettres dont vous gardez copie dans les archives de votre bureau.

Donc en somme cette raison devrait être suffisante pour ratifier l'admission en question, de Georges Russell Auger.

Cependant, puisque vous tenez toujours à venir à la question de religion, dont la loi civile devrait faire abstraction; car en bonne vérité si un individu manque à ses devoirs de conscience, elle n'a pas la charge de lui faire rectifier ses actes; mais peu importe, venons-en à la réalité.

Il est prouvé d'après les documents ci-inclus et les témoignages de sa femme, que Augustin Auger a été baptisé dans la religion catholique et qu'il n'a jamais pratiqué la religion protestante, qu'au contraire qu'il a toujours affirmé aux insinuations de sa femme, qu'il considère la religion catholique comme la vraie et que c'était sa foi. Si toutefois il a failli à l'un ou l'autre de ses devoirs, comme cela peut arriver malheureusement à chacun de nous, en fait réparation en faisant béni son mariage devant un prêtre catholique le 4 février dernier et en faisant une déclaration avoir la conscience en paix, si surtouts, un avenir prochain il doit comparaître devant Dieu; et le même motif il a pris la décision de faire élever ses enfants dans la religion catholique, qui est celle de son baptême et de son enfance.

Dear Sir:

Re George Russell Auger.

August Auger and his wife Gertie, the parents of George Russell, are members of the Church of England. I have approached them two or three times about putting their son George Russell in School, but each time they have said they would like to wait a little longer, as the father is very often sick and the boy is a help at home.

About the middle of January August was taken to the hospital at Desmarais, and his family has been staying there with him. Not long ago Gertie came to see me, and she told me that the priests at Desmarais had been asking her to put the boy George in School there. If the boy is to be put into School, I certainly feel he should be put into the Church of England School at Wabasca. Until the time that the family went to Desmarais, when August was taken to the hospital, there had never been any question that George would enter the Church of England School at Wabasca.

The eldest son, Joseph, is a registered pupil of this School.

Dear Sir,

Last January I received from the Acting Principal of the Wabasca R.C. Residential School an application made by Indian August Auger, No. 245 Wabasca Band, for the admission of his son George Russel to the R.C. School.

As August Auger had declared to me at the 1939 Treaty that he was a Protestant and as he has an older son in the Protestant School I have asked the principals of both schools to give theirs and the parent's reasons for sending his child to a school other than the protestant school.

I am now in receipt of the principals' letters which I enclose for your information. Will you kindly advise me in due course of your decision on the application.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo with reference to the application for the admission of Georges Russel Auger to the Wabasca R.C. Residential School.

Very careful consideration has been given to the contents of the letters which you forwarded and it has been decided not to approve the admission of this boy to any Indian residential school at the present time. If he is in a residential school you should arrange to have him return to his parents immediately.

About the middle of August you should interview the father and ascertain what religion he is recognized as professing and advise the Department. When this information is received further consideration will be given to the religious auspices under which Georges Russel Auger is to be educated.

Dear Sir,- Re Veronique Gambler, Register no. 107.

I beg to advise that the above mentioned girl is 16 years of age and wishes to be transferred to the Grouard school to take post-graduate course.

I feel assured that Veronique Gambler, who is of good moral character and is anxious to learn will surely profit by this course. I heartily recommend her admission at Grouard.

By the way, I may say that the Indian lads are doing very well in their farming operations at Wabasca. Five are now married and believe me, their young brides are proud of their homes furnished by the Department. The boys are now busy putting up plenty of hay in store for next winter. They will soon begin cutting their first crop of oats. Next winter, instead of buying oats which they usually paid one dollar per bushel to freight merchandise from Slave Lake to Wabasca, the boys are now realizing the great saving growing their own oats means to them.

As the lads do not have a machine to thresh their crop, I have arranged with them to do their threshing at the school, but it is hoped that they will be given one for next year, even though, it be only a small second hand one. I will discuss the matter with Mr. Agent L'Heureux first opportunity.

With every good wish and best regards,

I remain,

Yours truly,

L. Beuglet, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of April 3, in connection with the admission of George Russel Auger to the Wabasca R.C. Residential school.

I wish to report that I have interviewed the child's father on June 15th last. He was sick and looked at death's door. Doctor Conroy was in attendance.

In answer to my questions, August Auger stated definitely that he had returned to the faith of the Roman Catholic church in which he was born. There were exterior signs in his teepee showing that he was professing the Roman Catholic faith.

His wife, Gertie Alook, stated that she had been born and brought up in the Protestant Church, but that to comply to her husband's desire she herself had become a catholic rently.

August Auger reiterated the desire to have his children sent to a Roman Catholic School and that his son Joseph, aged 12, presently in the Wabasca C.E. School, be discharged from that school and transferred to the Catholic School at Desmaraies.

There appears no possibility of returning either of these two children to their family which is destitute following the lengthy illness of their parent. I have found it necessary to authorize the full complement of sick and iron rations and according to the doctor this man will not regain his health before many months.

Yours very truly,

N. P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

CANADA
Driftpile, Alberta,
October 11, 1941.

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith application of Headman August Auger, No. 119 Wabasca Band, for the readmission of her daughter Eliza, aged 10, to the Wabasca R.C. Residential School.

She has already attended that school for four years, her roll number was 0147. Last year her health broke down and as a consequence she was discharged. As her health has improved and is apparently normal it is desired to have her reinstated to her old number.

Referring to the physical examination report for that child I find that it has been made by Sister Denis D'Alexandrie, the school nurse, and find that it lacks indication as to her previous illness.

I take this opportunity to say that the Department has at Wabasca a paid resident Nurse in charge of a health unit. I am of opinion that the examination of prospective pupils should be made by her, not by the school nurse.

As regards this child, Eliza Auger, I am not satisfied. My information was that she showed signs of mental deficiency at the time of her discharge and I am submitting the application with the recommendation that admission be postponed until her examination has been made by Nurse Hamas.

Yours very truly,

N. P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Ottawa,
October 13, 1942.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to applications that you have submitted for Charles Gullion and Catherine Houle. The Department has been unable to locate the letter of August 20 which you state was written to Mr. L'Heureux.

However, while we requested application forms for the two children in our letter of July 27, this was only a routine request due to the fact that the names had been shown on the June quarter return without any applications having been submitted. The Department was not in a position to decide if the children were eligible for admission until we had reviewed the application forms.

As you are probably aware, the Department has deferred final decision regarding the discharge from Indian residential schools in your district of pupils whose parents are not now recognized as Indians. This decision does not apply to new pupils admitted within the last few months and whose applications have not been considered. In the cases under review the Department has decided that George Gullion and Bernard Houle cannot be recognized as Indians and consequently their children are not eligible for admission to an Indian residential school.

Yours truly,

Rev. Y.M. Floch, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Wabasca R.C. Residential School,
Desmarais, Alta.

Dear Sir:

Yours truly,

I am in receipt of a request from Treaty No. 111 Cree Band at Whitefish Lake, Mrs. Elizab Omizayak, to have two of her children, Theresa and Bella, transferred from the R.C. Indian Residential School at Wabasca to the R.C. Indian School at Grouard. The reason for this request is that at the present time the children are so far away from the parents that they cannot visit them. I have enquired into this request and it would seem to be of a reasonable nature and the parents are willing to pay the cost of this transfer. I have discussed this matter with Rev. Father Serrand of the Joussard School and he advises me that the Missions have no objection to such a transfer where the circumstances warrant it. Unless this is prohibited by Departmental regulations I believe that this would be beneficial in this case.

I have advised the parents that I am submitting their request to the Department for approval.

W.B. Skead
Acting Indian Agent.

15th October 1945.

Mr. P.J. Demers,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir,

I'm forwarding you three applications concerning girls over sixteen years of age but who have previously attended our school here.

According to the indigence of their family, it is quite hard for the parents to support these girls and keep them at their home and feed and clothe them.

So the parents asked me if I could take them at the Mission and give them work.

I would appreciate very much if the Department would consent to give the grant for these special cases, as we are keeping the girls here and at the same time we teach them the post-course of Household science.

Last year we have kept them during seven months, and this year again their parents asked me to take them and since the month of June the girls are here at the Mission.

As you know the mode of life of our Indians here in Wabasca, it is a protection for these girls to get a special attention from the Sisters and at the same time to increase their knowledge in domestic training.

Hoping that you will give your attention to this demand, and that the Department will give its approval as he did before regarding similar cases,

I remain sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Principal,

Desmarais, P.O.; Alberta.
Ottawa, 2nd November, 1945.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 15th ultimo, it is extremely difficult to approve the paying of a per capita allowance for girls of 18 and 19 years of age. The time must come when they are obliged to make their own way in life. It is simply impossible to keep children in school at such a late age if we are going to have accommodation for younger pupils reaching the school age.

However, we will make a special exception in these cases and will allow a grant for them until June 30th, 1946, provided they are within the authorized number for which a grant is allowed at the Wabasca R.C. School.

Sincerely yours,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, May 5, 1947.

Rev. B. Guimont, O.M.I., Principal, Wagasca R.C. Indian Residential School, Desmarais, Alberta.

With reference to the March Quarter Return of the Wabasca R.C. Indian Residential School, the following points are brought to your attention:

1. In the December Return No. 197 was allotted to Luke Bigstone, and on the March Return Luke Bigstone is omitted and No. 197 is allotted to Ubald Bigstone who had No. 198 in the December Quarter.

2. A number of pupils have been absent for more than two quarters and if they are not expected to return, the Department should be requested to approve their discharge.

3. In a case where a pupil is admitted to hospital up to thirty days grant is allowed. This applies to No. 0178 Sophie Beaver who was hospitalized from January 10th to March 10th and for whom forty-one days grant was requested. This should have been thirty-two days actually in school plus thirty days allowed for hospitalization making a total of sixty-two days. This also applies to pupils who lost three days on account of a tonsil operation. The Return has been adjusted and these children allowed the full ninety days grant.

The discharge of pupil No. 0177 is approved.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

16th February 1948

Mr. Phillip Melan
Chief Training Division,
Ottawa,

Dear Sir,

May I beg your attention on the following matter.

On the eleventh of December 1947 the Indians held a meeting under the presidency of the Indian Agent of Slave Lake Agency. There were many complaints against the Principal of the Church of England School at Wabasca, concerning the discipline, food and the way the children were treated at the above mentioned school. The parents are not satisfied.

On the next day of the meeting four Indians came here to ask me if I would take their children at our school. I told them to wait if there would be a change after that the Anglican has been advised of these complaints.

One of the Indians, George Car, tr: 154 waited two weeks and felt that there was no change for the better so he decide to bring his children here; he went to get them with his wife and brought them over here.

When Mr. Gooderham came in January, this case came up; Mr. Gooderham had a feeling that those children should be taken back to the Anglican Mission; but the father and mother of the children will no agree to do so, as they are perfectly satisfied the way the children are cared here and want them to stay here.

This family is recorded as protestant, but I understand the situation of whose parents whose desire is to have their children well brought up and well cared; and I believe that they have the natural right to do so towards their own children; this according to a letter from the Honourable E. Lapointe dated 23rd Nov. 1936 to our Principal of the time, also in a previous letter sent to Grounded by the Honourable Lomer Gouin on 7th Dec. 1922.

I cannot understand why these children could be forced to go back to a school where they do not receive the proper treatment.

The three children are in our school at present, and I am waiting on your decision before making any application for their admittance.

I remain sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Principal.
February 25, 1948.

Dear Father Guimont:

We have your letter of the 16th instant with reference to the children of George Oar.

I understand from your letter that the Oar family are recognised as Protestants. Sub-section (2) of Section 10 of the Indian Act reads as follows:

"No Protestant child should be assigned to a Roman Catholic school or school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices and no Roman Catholic child should be assigned to a Protestant school or school conducted under Protestant auspices."

In view of the section of the Indian Act just quoted, the Department is not able to approve the admission of the Oar children to the Wabasca R.C. School as grant earning pupils and their names should not be included on the quarterly return.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Rev. B. Guimont, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Wabasca R.C. Indian Res. School,
Desmarais, P.O., Alberta.
