Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.
Re: Yellowknese children

My dear Mr. Phelan:

Reverend Father Guimont, Principal of the Wabasca Indian Residential School, states in a letter received this morning that the above children are now living with their parents and attending the Catholic Day-School at Point St-Charles. He also says that for the time being, he is not taking any interest in them.

In this connection, Reverend Father Guimont wishes to bring to your attention the case of the Johny Cat family concerning which there was considerable correspondence in November 1944. At that time Mr. Hoey ordered the Protestant Minister to dismiss the Cat Children who were to be registered at and attend the Wabasca R.C. Indian Residential School. This Reverend Gentleman paid no attention to Mr. Hoey's letter. The two eldest children of this family were baptized Catholic and the third one Protestant. Moreover, the three youngest children were also baptized Catholic. The children of this family are in the Wabasca Anglican Indian Residential School.

Reverend Father Guimont also wishes me to bring to your notice the case of the Harvey Alook Family. It is true that the father was Protestant but he was married to a Catholic girl in the Catholic Church. Their first seven children were all baptized Catholics. They were brought to the Church for that purpose by their parents themselves. Moreover when one of these children died, a few years ago, the parents asked the Catholic Priest to attend the funeral service. These children are at the Wabasca Anglican Indian Residential School.
The above two cases are mentioned to illustrate the local difficulties.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

We are in receipt of a letter protesting against the attendance of Johnny Cat in the Wabasca C.E. Residential School.

In a letter dated January 16, 1945, the former Agent, Mr. P.J. Demers was advised that we were not prepared to approve the admission of Joseph and Johnny Cat to the Wabasca C.E. Residential School.

We have recently been informed that the children are still in that school in spite of the instructions contained in the letter to which we refer above. Please investigate the matter and let us have a report.

We also have a protest regarding the Harvey Alock family. We have been informed that their first seven children were all baptised Catholics and at the time one of the children died the funeral service was conducted in a Catholic church.

Please investigate the circumstances regarding this family and advise us.

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter of December 3rd file 768-10(E.l).

Recently I visited Wabasca and secured statements from the principals of the schools regarding the Harvey Alook family.

Reverend A.L. Davies, Principal of St. John's C.E. School stated that the father, Harvey Alook is Anglican. His wife Eleanor is Roman Catholic. The couple was married in the Roman Catholic Church. Some of the children were baptized Roman Catholic, some were baptized Anglican. The funeral service for Florence, who died in 1944, was conducted in a Roman Catholic Church. The funeral service for George Robert, who died in November 1946, was conducted in an Anglican Church.

Reverend A.L. Davies also stated that the Harvey Alook children have "always" attended the C.E. School to which he believes they were admitted by the Indian Affairs Branch. Rose and Vina Marie have been confirmed in the Anglican Church. Mrs. Alook attends the Wabasca Anglican Church.

Reverend Father Guimont, Principal of St. Martin's Roman Catholic School stated that Harvey Alook is Anglican. His wife is Roman Catholic. They were married by a Roman Catholic Missionary. All the children except George Robert were baptized Roman Catholics. The funeral service for Florence was conducted in a Roman Catholic Church.

The 1945 and 1946 copies of the Annuity Book show the Harvey Alook family, Treaty #263, as Anglican.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the
Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry,
consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical
Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's
presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of
Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's
death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be
permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked
if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be
attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after
the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it imprac-
ticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him.
A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal
Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind
might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for
this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach
the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including
an inquest, which may be required by law:

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the state-
ments of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

A Report on the Indians in the neighborhood of Whitefish Lake and other matters

Situation
Whitefish Lake lies north of Lesser Slave Lake, as the settlement of the latter lake is at its west end, the trail runs in a north-easterly direction to Whitefish Lake; for the first 13 miles it passes through a growing prairie, the soil of which is good, and capable of producing all kinds of cereals and roots, the rest of the trail runs through a bush country.

Nearly all the houses in this settlement are built on the East shore of the small Whitefish Lake, size about 34 miles by 15, it is joined to the big lake which is about 21 miles distant by a small river named Whitefish River.

Situation
These lakes are well known to all Indians, other lakes Long Lake lies 17 miles N.W. from Whitefish Lake, Fish Lake 15 miles from Whitefish Lake, Prairie Fish Lake, Lake and Buffalo Lake about 50 miles N.W. of here, two Otter Lakes, in the same direction about 110 miles from here, Fish Lakes about 125 miles N.W. of Whitefish Lake, Peace River is about 150 miles from Fish Lakes, Trout Lake 70 miles due East of Whitefish Lake, Cranberry Lake 50 miles N.E. from here, Lune Lake 50 miles North of here, Ghost Lake 6 miles West of here, another small Whitefish lake about 20 miles S.E. of here, there are a number of other smaller lakes besides these.

Soil
The soil on the shores of this lake is fairly good, a dark loam but shallow, when manured is capable of producing a good garden, some
Soil:
of the higher land the soil is deeper though of a lighter character, will stand more cropping without manure. At Prairie and Buffalo Lakes the soil is the best in this district, here some of the Indians have ploughed up small patches and put in potatoes and garden seeds, the produce of which I have seen, considering the time they were put in, they were very good crops.

Hay Lands:
There is an abundance of hay of a good quality found on the shores of the big Whitefish Lake, especially in a dry season on the small one there is a limited amount only found on one side. At Prairie and Buffalo Lakes the hay is plentiful and of a fair quality.

Timber:
In the vicinity of Prairie and Buffalo Lakes a considerable amount of good sized Spruce timber is to be found.

Fish:
White fish are not found in all the lakes in this district; in the three Whitefish Lakes they abound, and are of a fine quality, there are also many other varieties found in these waters, some white fish and other kinds found in Ghost Lake, no fish in Buffalo or Prairie, they are shallow lakes, no white fish but all other kinds at Long Lake, white fish are found at Fish Lakes, but of a smaller size than those at Whitefish Lake; some Trout at Cranberry Lake, no white fish at other Lakes.

Occupations of Indians:
All the Indians in this district are engaged in trapping during the winter, some occupy all their time, others a part of their time, those who own horses and sleighs, have the...
opportunity of doing some freighting or other work with their teams, while they are not engaged in looking after their traps.

In the Spring most of them put in a small garden of potatoes and vegetables, we impress upon them the importance, and the benefit from so doing (they are beginning to realize it now) we always have a good garden ourselves and provide them with a few seeds in the Spring so that they may follow our example, they are very fond of certain kinds of vegetables.

The haymaking season is quite a busy time with our Indians, it begins the latter part of July through August into September, they put up hay for their own stock, and thus the opportunity of making money by putting up hay for sale.

The next busy season which is a very important one, starts just before the freezing up of the rivers and lakes, during this time they catch their winter supply of fish. The exception to this rule, are only Indians who do not keep to this rule of fishing, are those on the shores of fish lakes, they begin their fishing through the ice about Christmas time.

The biggest settlement of Indians is on the shores of the smaller of the two Whitefish lakes, the Indians here have permanent log houses which they use in Winter close to their buildings they have their garden plot, and some a couple of acres of wheat, barley or oats, all fenced in.

We strongly encourage each family to have...
Occupations of its separate house, and we approve of the Indians and open fire place apart from a stove they may have, as this provides a constant ventilation, otherwise they would their houses unbearably hot and close, when an Indian is sick his one great idea is to keep his house as hot and close as possible.

At Fish Lakes there are about 30 Indians they have dwelling houses, and are permanently stationed there, as whitefish are found in these lakes it ensures it as a dwelling place for Indians, these people here are especially noted for their industry. There are about 25 Indians residing at Prairie Lake, as there are no fish in this lake, they do not stay so permanently as at other places where the whitefish abounds, as the people at this lake have a few cattle and horses they put up what hay they need to feed their stock during the winter months.

Long Lake is a place where Indians stay during the winter, and often visited in summer time. At Cranberry Lake there are a few houses which are used by the Indians in winter as this is one of their hunting grounds. There are about 50 Indians residing at Trout Lake. At Ghost Lake there are about 15 people, here they permanently reside, cultivate gardens and put up hay.

The Indians as a whole are fairly industrious, they build their own houses, make their own tents, canoes, dog sleighs, snow shoes, etc.

We employ women to do our washing scrubbing etc., very often young ones who have been...
Occupations of former pupils of the Home.

Indians and places of residence.

Sanitary conditions etc.

We enforce upon our Indians the necessity of clearing and raking round their houses every Spring and burning up old rubbish that in this way gathered up; they attend to this now regularly. We also encourage the whitewashing of their houses in and outside with a natural white mud which is to be found in certain parts of the big lake; it acts as a fertilizer.

As soon as the Spring sets in, the natives leave their houses for their tents where they live in until late in the Fall, up to the first heavy frost; they prefer the tents to their houses, and during Summer time, there is no doubt that they are better for them.

Educational work

The different subjects we teach our children are the following: Reading, Writing, Arithmetic, Geography, English, Drawing, Recitation, Singing, Cooking, Ethics, General Knowledge, and Religious Instruction.

We lay much stress on the necessity of them being industrious, learning cleanliness, neatness and truthfulness encouraging them to take a pride in doing their part to keep the Home clean. The girls are fond of cooking when they leave the Home we visit them when we can, and try and help them carry out what they have learnt. We can do this more effectually when they have houses of their own which method as I have before mentioned, we strongly enforce upon them. We make the boys do all kinds of outside work.
Where children, our Indians have three separate reserves, we are permitted to gather the most of our children from the reserve on the shores of this lake, as the greatest number of the Indians reside here; last winter we had one child from Prairie Lake, we have only one child in continuous residence.

Dear Mr. Copper,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your address of Nov. 26th. I am thankful for the grant of $500 towards the Lesser Slave Lake School which will about cover the support of the number of treaty children admitted.

Re your remark about day schools, viz., "I may say that it is not the present policy of the Dept. to enter into the boarding school system but to enlarge and extend the usefulness of the day schools." This may apply to some parts of the Dominion but I think that you know as well as me that to apply it to such districts as Whitefish, Wapiti, means no school and no education. How many children would you find within reach of a day School in Athabasca? I can assure you that the Dept. to replace the boarding schools by day schools, but to do it in the present condition of the Country simply means closing down altogether. This said, he willing to do, for a time, if applied to the Roman Catholic as well, but it never will.

The refusal to increase the number of children to gain the per Capita Grant is a very serious matter. I have already stated that it is impossible to go on paying our Staff with only a per Capita grant for 30 children. The same Staff would
Required for 30 would be sufficient for twice that number. I have paid for provisions and other necessaries alone, apart from salaries, for 1907 over $2000, and the total of grants, including the teacher's grant of $200, does not amount to more than $1100. I do not mean to say that it shall cost $2000 for support in future, but as you know they had 34 children, boarders, in all districts. This abnormal number was no doubt due to the poverty of the Indians, who knew that they could not be able to feed and clothe their children. So it amounted to this, that the Council had the responsibility of feeding, clothing, instructing Indians. There are places where you, as Inspector, are well acquainted with, and I believe, we rely upon you to make them known to the Minister of the Interior or other Officers in the Dept.

My aim is to try to reduce the number of Boarding Schools as soon as possible, but the most hopeful place will be those where the Indians are chief wards of the Court will not, in our day, be able to send their children to a day school; and for the support of these, I do think the Council ought to bear the lion's share of financial responsibilities.

I humbly beg you to persevere in this matter, as the matter concerning the industrial moral welfare of the Indians under your charge—my appeal to the Dept., as you know, a very reasonable one—a modest in the extreme. We are not disrespectful.
For all the Government leave due for the Indians. On the contrary, we are most thankful. But our grants from all missionary societies are rapidly diminishing, and it is already impossible to allow large grants as hitherto towards the support of these schools.

Meeting that you may yet be able to influence the Dept. in favour of an increase in the per capita grant at the future places. The Rev. R. Wilson & Peace River wrote that the Chief has bought four treaty children who had already been. Now what would the Dept. advise in this case? ought we to refuse them? If the Dept. are unable to make any allowance there will be no alternative. Also to do this is practically driving our own people from our doors to seek admittance elsewhere. Kindly excuse me writing at this length but the business is urgent.

With kindest regards & best wishes for the approaching Yule tide.

Yours very sincerely,

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Bishop Holmes, of Athabasca, has renewed the request for an increased grant to the Church of England Boarding Schools at Wabiskaw Lake and Whitefish Lake, Treaty 8, and for a day school grant at Peace River.

We have lately made them a day school grant at Lesser Slave Lake and in 1904-05 a grant of $300.00 for the Peace River school was voted. No returns were received from December, 1907, till December, 1909. The latter was received a few days ago and payment has been made.

While I would not recommend making an exception in favour of these two boarding schools in the matter of per capita grant I am of opinion that the question of an increase in the pupilage is worthy of consideration.

The returns from the Wabiskaw school show that in the June quarter, last, there were enrolled 27 pupils and in the December quarter 19. His Lordship claims that this reduction was made because they could not afford to keep any in excess of the number for whom the Department will pay the grant; not because of any lack of pupils. There has also been a reduction in the number maintained at Whitefish Lake.

There are several arguments that might be advanced in favour of an increased pupilage at these points.

In the first place the same staff is required to conduct a school for 15, the number now allowed, as for 25, pupils, the number asked for.

The cost of supplies in these outlying posts is very high, caused principally by the excessive freight rates.

Day schools are and for sometime will be impracticable in this district, as the Indians will depend upon the hunt for their living for years yet.

The Honourable the Superintendent General-

10. St Bruno, Jousard, Alta.

The above is a partial list of residential schools in connection with which the Department pays a per capita grant. In these cases the Department did not build the schools and does not exercise the rights of ownership. It is noted that the last seven in the above list are in one agency i.e., the Grouard Agency.

In a number of these cases the Department is being asked to assume financial responsibility and to pay grants towards the capital costs of the buildings, besides making additional grants for additions, repairs and maintenance. In at least two instances there are undertakings on the part of the Department to furnish certain financial assistance. Many of the arrangements made and paid in this connection have been verbal in nature and the terms are not of definite record. It would seem clear, however, that in some, if not all cases the Department is obligated to some degree at least, but the lack of written records and agreements makes it very difficult to determine the nature and extent of this responsibility.

The fact that the Department has undertaken the payment of per capita grants implies a certain responsibility for the up-keep of the buildings, if not for the capital costs.

In my opinion it is necessary that the Department adopt a general policy for the purpose of dealing with these difficulties and I would respectfully offer the following suggestions for your consideration:
1. That the Department of Indian Affairs undertake the payment of per capital grants and any financial aid towards the cost of building only when the prior authority of the Department has been granted. This authority should cover such matters as site, size and nature of school buildings.

2. That such authority in all cases be set out in a formal and definitely worded agreement for the guidance of Departmental officials, as a matter of record and for the purpose of avoiding future misunderstandings.

3. That the schools now operating by authority of the Department as recognized by the payment of per capita grants be assisted from time to time as circumstances warrant and financial conditions permit.

4. That the various missionary societies be notified of the above rulings.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

You will recall that during my recent visit to Ottawa (November 21st) you requested me to write to you about certain items of business which I discussed with you and the Director of your branch of Government, and I am now acceding to this request.

One of these items of business was an official increase in the pupilage of our White Fish Lake School at Atikameg, Alta., from 30 to 40.

For your information I may say that the addition to this school recently completed, provides, according to word received from the Principal, adequate accommodation for the increase requested, and I most earnestly hope that it may be granted.

In the comprehensive list of requirements submitted by our Commission to be met by your branch of Government next year, a new school building was included at an estimated cost of $35,000.00. While there can be no doubt whatever about the need of a new building to supersede the one in use at present, and built with church funds, the increased pupilage will be a very material help to our society at this critical and anxious time, should it be found impossible for the Government to build the new and larger building during the fiscal year 1939-1940.

For your information regarding present conditions at this School and Mission, and to show that our Church is
doing all within her power to help forward the Indian work at this centre, I am able to quote the following from a letter from our Bishop of Athabasca, the Rt. Rev. Dr. A.H. Sovereign, who recently visited White Fish Lake, and wrote to me on the 2nd instant:-

"I have just returned from a visit to Whitefish Lake, and our Indian Mission at that point, and I think I should send you my impression of the work being carried on at that Post.

May I say that I was quite delighted. The staff is a very capable and efficient body of workers, possibly the best that I have yet seen at that point. I am sure you would be delighted. Mr. Cathcart comes with endless energy and with splendid ideas, and they are gradually working out. The new Matron is exceedingly capable, and everything has been systematised with the background of a nurse's training. Her nursing experience is also a great help to the whole community. The new teacher is thoroughly trained and very capable. I feel that we should always have a teacher at our Indian Schools who has had a normal training, for teaching is a science. Miss Swift is doing excellent work as Kitchen Matron. Mr. Reynolds as farm instructor is also very acceptable. There seemed to be a fine spirit pervading the whole institution. The children were well and happy. I noticed with great satisfaction the following improvements:- New fences everywhere, new land being broken between the School and the Lake where they will soon have an excellent garden-site, a new root-house for the storing of vegetables, and a workshop in the front of it. They will have sufficient vegetables evidently for the whole winter. New land of over forty acres has been obtained through the Diocese, and will be used for the raising of hay and as a wood supply. This land lies between our Mission land and the R.C. property. This now gives us excellent Mission lands. The graveyard has been cleaned up and put in order, and a large area to the east has been cleared up as an addition. A new dormitory has been built for the boys, a fine new dining-hall and bright and commodious rooms for the staff. A new community hall about 35' x 60' is being built, and logs and lumber are on hand for a new church. These have been provided through the Diocese and through the generosity of the community itself. A new cow-stable is under building, and a new corral for the cattle. The old rectory has been repaired and re-planned with excellent effect, and cupboards etc., have been installed in the school buildings. I was quite pleased with everything. I sincerely hope that it may be possible for us to construct a new modern school at this strategic post. We must not in any way decrease our efforts, both at this Mission and also at Wabasca. I am more than ever..."
"convinced that we should have two separate schools at these respective points."

As the July-September returns for this School showed 41 pupils enrolled, though 8 of them had been wrongfully admitted to the Roman Catholic School, there can be no doubt that a capacity enrollment of forty could easily be secured if the official pupilage were increased to that number and I would repeat the very earnest hope already expressed above, that this increase be granted.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Crerar:

During my visit to Ottawa on the 9th ultimo, I was informed that you had under consideration, as an economic measure, the question of closing at least two of our Society's Indian Residential Schools, namely, St. Andrew's at White Fish Lake (Atikameg, P.C.) and St. John's at Wabasca, both in northern Alberta, and of establishing Indian Day or Improved Indian Day Schools instead. This information was duly presented to our Commission, when the members, under the Chairmanship of His Grace, the Archbishop of Rupert's Land, unanimously decided to recommend to the Executive Committee of our Society, that you be earnestly requested to refrain from making any alteration whatever in the status of these schools during the duration of the prevailing war.

The Commission's decision has been communicated to the Executive Committee, but as the General Secretary (Canon L.A. Dixon, M.A., D.D., O.B.E.) is at present absent from Toronto, and as the Executive will not meet until towards the end of the current month of November, I have thought it advisable, seeing that the Estimates for the Indian Affairs Branch for the coming fiscal year are now in the course of preparation, to write to you at once in the matter. In due course, you will, no doubt, hear from our Society's General Secretary in this connexion.

While the members of our Commission are as keenly desirous of effecting economies at the present time, as any group of loyal citizens could possibly be, they are convinced that the change you have under contemplation would not produce the result you desire. A careful examination of the expenditures made by the Government during recent years for these two schools, and a comparison of
the same with an estimate of what expenditures would have to be made to provide and equip and maintain the type of school suggested, leaves no doubt in the mind of any member of our Commission that the change, so far as effecting economies are concerned, would not be justified.

Further, as a very considerable number of the Indian children now in residence at these schools come from too great a distance to be able to attend daily, they would be deprived of the educational facilities which the existing schools provide.

There are other considerations in connexion with this question which are of vital importance to the Missionary Society of our Church and the members of our Commission desired me to say that they would greatly appreciate an opportunity of discussing some of these with you sometime when you happen to be in Winnipeg.

With highest regards,

Yours very truly,

T.B.R. Westgate,
Secretary of the Commission.

With reference to Mr. Jackson's memorandum of March 19, I wish to supply the following additional information regarding the Whitefish Lake School:

The Whitefish Lake School is in the Lesser Slave Lake Agency and in this agency there are two Indian Residential Schools, operated under the auspices of the Church of England. Both of these buildings are church-owned. The authorized pupilage at these two schools is as follows:

| Location       | Pupilage |
|----------------|----------|
| Wabasca        | 35       |
| Whitefish Lake | 30       |
| Total          | 65       |

In the 1944 Census the religion of the Indians in this agency is not stated. Consequently, to give you an idea of the religious affiliations of the Indians in the Lesser Slave Lake Agency, I supply the following information from the 1939 Census:

- Number in Band: 3238
- Number of Church of England Indians: 292
- Number of Roman Catholic Indians: 2296

The above figures show that the Indians who are adherents of the Church of England number approximately 9% of the total Indian population in the agency.

The 1939 census also shows that at that time there were 798 children between 7 and 16 years of age. Presumably, at least 9% of these would be children whose parents are adherents of the Church of England. This would mean that...
approximately 71 children of school age would require education under Church of England auspices.

From the above figures, you will note that while there were approximately 71 children there was accommodation provided in the two residential schools for 65.

I wish also to direct your attention to a letter dated November 3, 1941, from Reverend T.B.R. Westgate, Secretary of the M.S.C.C. This letter was addressed to the Honourable Mr. Crerar and expressed the opinion that day schools would not be satisfactory in that particular area. As stated in my memorandum of March 8, there have been frequent requests from the Church of England for the inclusion of an item of approximately $35,000.00 in our appropriation, in order to provide a new residential school at Whitefish Lake. Mr. Hoey

Miss Marshall advised she had received disturbing information from a teacher at the Whitefish school that the principal there had stripped the girls and strapped them. It appears that the astron had lost $15.00 on the road to the White Bay Store. One of the Indian children had found $5.00 and instead of returning it to the principal spent part of it to buy candles and biscuits which were distributed amongst the girls. Miss Marshall stated that the teacher concerned wanted to travel to Ottawa, at her own expense, to report the Director of the disrespectful treatment, but on her advice abandoned the idea. I told Nurse Marshall that the charge was a very serious one and asked her to obtain a written statement from the teacher and submit a full report. The nurse also stated that when she was examining the girls and filling in their history charts the principal insisted she was taking up too much time and going to too much trouble. He told her all that was necessary for him to do was to sign the cards and he would "fill in the information." Miss Marshall was making stethoscope tests of the girls, with the upper parts of their bodies exposed, and she required a private room where it would be less noisy. The principal insisted he should be present in the room to fill in the cards but Miss Marshall would not permit him. The principal was reluctant to permit her to use medical supplies from the stock stored at the school, and told her that these supplies were at her disposal when required, and instructed that she communicate with Dr. F. E. Moore, Medical Superintendent of the Indian Health Service, who undoubtedly would provide her with a letter authorising her to use any of the medicines, at any of the schools, where he commended upon her work. The nurse also stated that one of the fifteen year old boys from the school ran down through the bush to the lake, where the plains were waiting, to report to her of the strapplings he had received since he knew he would get additional punishment but he did not care what would happen to him as he felt that these unjust beatings should be reported. Miss Marshall is a very conscientious, capable and efficient person, and I feel that she would not have advised me of this condition unless she sincerely believed it to be true.

I would therefore recommend that Mr. M. McCrimmon, on his next visit to the Lesser Slave Lake Agency, be instructed to investigate these charges completely and fully, and submit a report so that - if the charges are confirmed - the necessary disciplinary action may be taken.

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

Projected Whitefish Lake Indian Day School

Further to our conversation with Canon Cook this morning I wish to add to the file for purposes of record the following:

We still lack any written communication from the Alberta Education Department's Director of Administration (Mr. H.E. Balfour).

A second teacher will be necessary in place of Miss Powell who now reports that she is not available. I think that Mr. Gooderham has one or two Alberta people who would be interested in the assignment.

Rental at the figures suggested seems in order i.e., $20. for each classroom and $10. for living quarters for the teachers.

Mr. Superintendent Lapp will have to assume the provision of fuel and water.

There is what was a good lighting plant but the Diesel engine which is Church property ought to be taken "outside" and repaired by experts. There is a mail carrier who makes the trip by wagon between Whitefish Lake and the railway station at Grouard. I suggest some arrangement between our Superintendent and Diocesan headquarters at Peace River, Alberta or with the Church representative who takes over from the Reverend E.W. Johnson at Whitefish Lake.
I am hoping that the two teachers can work and live in one building but this is subject to the reaction of the successor to the Reverend Mr. Johnson. My telegram of June 23 to Mr. Superintendent Lapp refers to this matter.

Furniture for the teachers appears to exist on the spot and the provision of this may be regarded as a contribution by the Church to the comfort of the teachers who may be expected to be adherents of the Church of England.

As we hope for concerted action in the province it is to be understood, I hope, by all parties, that the regulations for religious instruction for the public schools of Alberta will be followed.

Arrangements for enforcing the attendance of non-Indians should be clarified so that there is no loop-hole by which these children will escape attending one of the schools (i.e., either this one or Atikameg), because the example is likely to be followed by the Indian children. Once again it seems necessary for me to urge that school registers be faithfully kept or that those responsible be penalized. We might request further opinions from Mr. Balfour and Departmental field officials. I would prefer to abandon the lean-to in favour of unifying school facilities and living quarters in the same large building. The half-finished community hall might become available as play space for the children later.

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

Memorandum:

INPUT MINISTER

Whitefish Lake Residential School

The above Residential School is situated at Atikameg in northern Alberta. It has been operated in old buildings, many of them of log construction and presenting a definite fire hazard. Two years ago it was found that the school still used oil and gasoline lanterns and was heated with small stoves.

It had only a pupilage of 30 and was operated by the Indian School Administration of the M.S.C.C.

As a result of an educational survey, it was decided, with the agreement of the M.S.C.C., to take the following action:

(a) Erect a new dormitory block at the Wabasca Anglican Residential School situated in the same agency, which would provide safe accommodation for the children at both Wabasca and at Whitefish Lake who required institutional care;

(b) To erect a two-room day school at Whitefish Lake for the Protestant children living there (we already have a Catholic day school at Atikameg - which is the Indian word for Whitefish Lake).

I attach a series of photographs which will give you a factual presentation of the school as it existed. The photographs are numbered as follows:

1. The residential school classroom is at the left with the teachers' living quarters in the next log building.
2. The community hall.

3. The community hall from another angle.

4. Interior of the community hall, showing finishing materials.

5. Interior of classroom.

6. Teacher and "white" children - these are really half-breeds and we are corresponding with the Alberta Department of Education concerning a joint school for them.

7. Chief and Councillors.

8. Atikameg R. C. School, - erected by Department three years ago.

I would recommend the Minister's approval of the following action:

(a) The closing of the Whitefish Lake Residential School as of June 30, 1950.

(b) The opening, in temporary quarters, of the Whitefish Lake Indian Day School as of 1 September, 1950.

(c) The continuance of negotiations with the Alberta Department of Education for the operation of a joint school at this point. (Our Educational Survey Officer will soon be leaving for the West).

Dear Sir:-

--REPAIRS REQUIRED AT WHITE FISH LAKE--

The Principal of our Society's school at White Fish Lake, Alta., writing on July 19, states as follows:

"I am sorry to say that on July 5, we had a hail storm which broke seven windows in the main school building, two in the Mission house, and did a great deal of damage to the roof of the school, including the kitchen roof, as well as the roofs of the stores and other buildings. The roofs were all in a bad condition before the storm, as the boards and shingles had been on so long, and in places were quite rotten. When the rain came on, I had to put a tent of mine on the top of the roof of the main building, to prevent our provisions and other things from being destroyed.

The Principal did not furnish me with an estimate of what it would cost to have the roofs thus damaged sufficiently repaired to enable him and his staff to carry on their work for another year or two, but it seems to me that this could not be effected at a cost of less than £500, and I write to ask if you will kindly authorize the expenditure of that amount for this purpose.

I remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Re White Fish Lake School C. of E.

With further reference to your letter of the 3rd inst., (No.131-10-5) in which you decline to authorize any expenditure for repairs to our Society's School at White Fish Lake, and offering the recommendation that logs be taken out this winter and a new building erected in the Spring, I beg to state that so far as our Society is concerned the recommendation for the erection of a log building is wholly unacceptable. On page 2, section 4, subsection (a) of my letter to the Deputy Superintendent General dated Nov. 22, 1923 it is stated in the list of Residential Schools required by our Society that a "new School should be established at Lesser Slave Lake with increased capacity of enrolment to take the place of the one now established there and the one at White Fish Lake."

Our Society is still of the opinion that the provision of the new and enlarged School therein suggested will afford the best and most economical solution to the problem of Indian Education in that part, and I trust that your Department may approve of this arrangement and undertake the erection of a modern and fully equipped building at an early date.

As the erection of new School buildings for our Society at other centres have a prior claim on your Department it is necessary that the present buildings at both White Fish Lake and Lesser Slave Lake should be made habitable for at least another year, and it is for this reason that I feel constrained to again ask you to give favourable consideration to the request for $500. for repairs contained in my letter of August 6th last.

I have the honour to be, Sir

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

October 21, 1924.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

Some weeks ago Dr. Westgate requested that $500 be allowed to repair the main building at the Whitefish Lake Indian Residential School. I asked Mr. Indian Agent Laird for a recommendation and he reports that it would be a waste of material to repair the present building. He suggested that logs be taken out this winter and a new building erected in the spring. The agent reports that the main timbers are decayed and the floor joists are in bad condition.

I acquainted Dr. Westgate with the nature of this recommendation and he cannot agree to a log structure in place of the main building at this school. He draws the Department's attention to the fact that a new and modern building at Whitefish Lake is one of the L.S.C.C. major requests and that, as it may not be possible to secure an appropriation for the purpose for next year (building season 1925), he urges that repairs be undertaken, so that the work may be carried on until a new building is provided.

I shall be pleased to have your instructions. It was estimated that the repairs would cost approximately $500.

Russell J. Ferrier
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

When I telephoned to you from Grouard on the 3rd instant after consulting Mr. Indian Agent Laird stating that I considered $2000.00 would be sufficient to meet the repairs at this school, I had in mind the urgent need of a separate class room which it was thought could be supplied for $1000.00. The provision of this would have been a great comfort to the staff and pupils, and have added much to the efficiency of the School. I regret that it was not actually named in the list of requirements forwarded to your Department last Autumn to be supplied this year, but it was included in the repairs to the Main School Building etc., and it was thought the sum of $3000.00 requested would cover the cost of the same. Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, relative to the erection of the proposed new classroom at the Whitefish Lake (St. Andrew's) Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have this work carried out on a day labour basis, under the charge of a competent foreman. You should co-operate with the Principal of the School in carrying out the work, and it is thought that he could supervise same, and see that a satisfactory job is completed. The work of erecting the new classroom should be undertaken as soon as weather conditions permit.

Returns of the labour employed should be prepared, in duplicate, on the forms for that purpose, a supply of which is being sent you. An accountable cheque for $400 to pay the labour is also being sent you under separate cover, and this you should account for in the usual manner by forwarding the returns of the labour employed, properly certified. Should you require a further advance at a later date to pay the labour, you should apply for same, stating the amount required. The Principal would, no doubt, arrange to see that proper returns of the labour employed are kept.

Accounts, in duplicate, properly certified should also be forwarded by you covering the cost of the building material and for any freight charges.

The Department will leave the matter of the erection of the classroom in your hands to have the work satisfactorily completed, as cheaply as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of the 17th inst., re the absence of fire escapes from the dormitories at the Whitefish Lake School, and in reply I beg to state that I discussed this matter with the Rev. C. D. White, Principal of this school, when he passed through Winnipeg a few days ago on his way to England on furlough. The main school building, as you may know, is made of logs and was built by our Church some years ago. The height from the dormitory window to the ground is not so great that a child would receive much injury if it jumped from the window to a mattress on the ground or some other safe object. It seems to me that as the building itself is more like a big farmhouse than a school, little difficulty would be found in removing all the children from the school by the present exits. However, as your Department appears to consider it essential that a supplementary exit be provided, I am instructing Mr. Stone, who is in charge of the school during Mr. White's absence, to have a fire escape made of peeled poplar poles with one end embedded in the ground some distance away from the building, and the other resting against the building itself at the upstairs dormitory window. This kind of fire escape has been installed at our Hay River School, and I trust that it may meet with your approval. I am also reminding Mr. Stone of the instructions issued some time ago to all Principals to have a fire drill to be practised regularly by the pupils.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.S.

Dear Sir:-

The Rev. C. D. White, Principal of our Society's Indian Residential School at White Fish Lake, Alta., is very anxious to know what improvements at this school have been sanctioned by your Department for the current fiscal year.

In the list of requirements submitted to you by our Commission in the autumn of 1929, the sum of $500.00 was specified in this connection, provided the amalgamation of our three schools in Northern Alberta could not be undertaken this year.

When I visited this school in March of the current calendar year, I made a list of the most urgent requirements, and these were as follows:

1. Renewal of foundation logs in the main school building $200.00 (This school was built in 1906 and the foundation has not been renewed since).
2. Lining the class-room with beaver board ............... 100.00
3. Building a new cow stable .................................. 300.00
4. Building an implement shed .................................. 250.00
5. Lumber for general repairs .................................. 100.00

On April 15th I made known to you these urgent needs, and on April 28th your reply stated that as your Department hoped to replace these three institutions in the not distant future, and as your appropriation was extremely limited, no items were included for replacement or repairs at these three schools. You also suggested that the management get along as well as they could with the equipment now on hand.

As the contemplated amalgamation has not taken place, and
likely to be deferred, so far as I can see at present, for at least another year, I am convinced some improvements must be undertaken at once.

As this is the time of year when the logs required for these improvements could be secured to the best advantage, I shall be glad to know if your Department will authorize an expenditure for this purpose, and the amount of the same. The total estimated cost of the improvements, including materials and labour, is approximately $1,000.00. If you will authorize an expenditure of $500.00 for the materials, I will ask the Principal to arrange for payment to be made after April 1st of next year, when a further sum of $500.00 will be required to meet the cost of labour.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report of an inspection which I made of several residential schools in the Lesser Slave Lake Agency on the occasion of my recent visit to that district. The schools visited were:

- St. Andrew's at Whitefish Lake
- St. Peter's & St. Bernard's at Grouard
- St. Bruno's on the Lesser Slave Lake
- St. Francois Xavier in the Grande Prairie District

ST. ANDREW'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (C. of E.)
WHITEFISH LAKE RESERVE.

This school is situated on the Little Whitefish Lake, and is 45 miles north east of Grouard, and about 60 miles from Emilda, the closest railway point on the Northern Alberta Railway to the school. The road in from Grouard, for the greatest part, has been cut through a heavy growth of bush, and during the summer months I can readily see that at times it would be difficult to freight in supplies, but during the winter, when the muskegs and lakes are frozen over, the question of transportation is not a difficult one.

I visited this school on February 10th, and found 22 children in attendance, 10 boys and 12 girls. There were also 3 non-treaty children attending as day scholars. The Rev. C. D. White is in charge as Principal.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
ST. ANDREW'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (S. of E.) Cont'd.

as Principal and has acted as such for many years. He has, as assistants, Mr. James Stone, teacher, who is non-professional, Miss Punchard, matron, and Mrs. Howe, cook.

The buildings include the residence for the children, a residence for the Principal, a separate building for a classroom, a horse and cow stable, as well as a storehouse. All the buildings have been constructed with log walls. The Principal's residence was erected about thirty-five years ago. The residence for the children was erected over twenty-five years ago. This building was not placed on a foundation in the first instance; the foundation logs have rotted, which makes the floors very uneven and has put the windows and doors out of line. The cellar is merely a hole in the ground. The building provides a kitchen, a small staff dining room, a girls' playroom, which is also used as a community room for holding services and so forth, a small dining room, which is also used as a playroom for the boys during the winter months. The upstairs provides two staff bedrooms, one for the lady members, and the other for the teacher who supervises the boys. The boys' dormitory is 16' x 18', with a pitched roof, the inside of which has not been ceiled, and consequently provides a certain amount of ventilation through the cracks. There are 9 beds in this dormitory for 10 boys, two of the younger ones having to double up. The girls' dormitory is 15' x 20' in size, with a pitched roof similar to that of the boys'. There are 11 beds for 12 girls, 2 of the smaller ones having to sleep together.

ST. ANDREW'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (C.of E.) Cont'd.

The windows in this building are small and narrow, each sash containing 4 - 10" x 12" lights.

A few wash basins are provided in each dormitory, and individual towels, as well as tooth brushes, are supplied. The conveniences in this school are necessarily rather primitive. Coal oil lamps are used for lighting and box stoves for heating purposes.

Six Pyrene fire extinguishers are placed at convenient points throughout the building. The water supply is obtained from the Whitefish Lake, and has to be hauled to the building. There is no adequate provision made for water storage. Ladders, which can be leaned up against the windows, are provided as a means of escape in case of fire.

The washing for the school is all done in the kitchen as they have no other place in which to do it. The consequence is that during the winter months, on wash days, the school is not a very pleasant place, and the clothes are hung up to dry in the kitchen, the girls' playroom, the dining room, and, in fact, practically the whole building has to be utilised. On the evening of my arrival, which was on wash day, when I entered the school I had to dodge clothes lines. These are difficulties which have to be put up with in the older class of schools such as this. The floors are rough and uneven, but I found them very clean. As a matter of fact, the building was in a very creditable condition considering the class of building it is, and I can readily understand that it is a difficult matter to keep
ST. ANDREW'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (C.of E.) Cont'd.

matter to keep this building in presentable shape. A new building is badly required.

The classroom is a new log building 19' x 21', with a 9 ft. ceiling. It is lighted by 4 small windows, one at each side of the door in front, and 2 at the end. These windows have 4 - 10x12 lights in each sash. It will be readily understood that these small windows in a thick log wall do not give very much light. If the front windows were doubled up, it would greatly improve the lighting and at no very great cost.

The children have a healthy, clean, and bright appearance. They looked well nourished. I saw them at their evening meal, and noted that ample good, wholesome food was supplied for the meal. They have porridge and milk, as well as bread and lard for breakfast, meat and vegetables daily for dinner, and for their supper they get bread and lard, as well as fruit, puddings, and so forth.

A sufficiently large garden is planted each year to provide potatoes and other vegetables for the requirements of the school. The sample of potatoes shown me was of very good quality, and the Principal tells me that they have no difficulty in raising all the vegetables they require.

The Principal appears to be a very earnest and kindly man. I am sure that his presence on the reserve exerts a good influence on the Indians.

Separate outside toilets are provided for the boys and for the girls. I found these toilets in a cleanly condition.

They need
ST. ANDREW'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (C.oF.E.) Cont'd.

They need a new cow stable very badly. The present one was built over thirty years ago and is falling down.

In keeping with the arrangement suggested by the late Mr. Ferrier, Superintendent of Indian Education, and approved by our Commission, the list of buildings which it is desired should be provided next year, is recorded on a separate sheet (sheet 2), and is followed by information showing the necessity of the buildings mentioned (sheets 3 and 3 continued). The suggestion having been made to the Commission that any scheme for the amalgamation of the White Fish Lake and Wabasee...
Schools, might be extended so as to embrace the activities of the Hay River School as well, with the possibility of having the amalgamated School located at a central point such as Fort McMurray, the members carefully considered the same, but were convinced that this arrangement would not be feasible. In addition to the difficulty already referred to in the enclosed statement, relative to bringing the present pupilage of the Hay River School further south, there would be the equally great difficulty of bringing the present pupilage of the White Fish Lake and Wabasca Schools to Fort McMurray via Edmonton. PB CALGARY, ALTA., November 30th, 1934.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 160-2 of the 24th instant in connection with Indian Residential Schools under the auspices of the Church of England in the Peace River country. I have also read over carefully the copy of your letter to Doctor Westgate from which I take it that his suggestion was to consolidate the schools at the Whitefish Lake and Wabasca Reserves and build a modern structure at the Eastern end of Lesser Slave Lake.

Personally I think this arrangement would not be very satisfactory as the school would be located too far from the recruiting ground. As you are aware, the Roman Catholic Church have a large school at Wabasca and just speaking from memory, when I was there last year ago last summer there were 85 Indian children and 40 Halfbreed children in the school. At the mission about 7 miles distant, there were 30 children. What will happen there if the school is closed down and one built at Slave Lake is that the Anglican parents at Wabasca will all join the R.C. church so that they can send their children to that institution at Wabasca, and in a short time we would not be able to recruit any children from there with the exception of a few orphans; Not that I have any concern as to which church the Indians belong to, but I am merely pointing out what is liable to be the outcome of the proposed change if put into effect, as it has so happened at other places. The roads from Wabasca to Slave Lake a distance of about 100 miles are practically impassible in the winter and especially in wet weather, and I have been informed that the only way you can get through is with team and lumber wagon with a small load.

A situation similar to the above would arise at Whitefish Lake and we would have the same difficulty in recruiting children for the new school from there. The Indians would gradually go over to the R.C. Church so that they could send their children to Groberg instead of to a school down at the South end of the lake. As far as I know there is no trail on the North side of Slave Lake and they would have to be brought up to Groberg and then down the South side of the lake to wherever the school was built, and this would be at least another 100 miles. There may, however, be some trail straight through that I do not know if.

I am sure Dr. Westgate is aware of the difficulties encountered in recruiting for a school that is any great distance from the reserve, Elkhorn, for instance, and I think this matter should receive a great deal of thought before any change is made. I might state that to the best of my knowledge the reserves along Lesser Slave Lake are almost hundred per-cent Roman Catholic.

Dear Mr. Orr:

As this is my first letter to you in 1936, I shall commence by wishing you and yours (including your favourite Scottie) health, happiness and prosperity throughout the year upon which we have entered.

Pursuant to my Report on the Whitefish Lake project, I had a talk on the subject with Mr. Inspector Christianson this morning, and on his suggestion I am writing you now to bring prominently to your attention the need of establishing a camp in advance of building operations, if it is the intention to build this year.

Because of the remoteness of the place, and the absence of accommodation, it would appear very necessary to provide a storage shed for such materials as cement, lime, gypsum, etc., which would require protection from the weather. Then there should be a bunk-house for workmen, and a mess-house for meals. Stoves, tables, benches and bunks should be provided. Lumber for these buildings, nails, roofing paper, stoves, etc., could be shipped in, and the buildings erected, previous to the general hauling of building materials. The teamsters would then have somewhere to eat and sleep after the long haul through the wilds; and these temporary buildings would also house the artisans who would come later.

It is therefore respectfully suggested that if the Department decides to build the proposed school this year, that authority be given to proceed as early as possible in providing the essential temporary buildings. I have had previous experience in setting up working camps, and, if so instructed, would be pleased to undertake this preliminary preparation, and perform any other services which the Department might require.

In anticipation of the Department's authority, I shall draw rough plans of the suggested temporary buildings, and prepare a list of materials required, so that there need be no
avoidable delay if authority comes to proceed with this work. These buildings, would of course, be of inexpensive type, but suitable for the purposes in view, and could probably be utilized as outbuildings by the Mission afterwards as has been the case in some other instances.

Dear Sir:

Report on Proposed School, White Fish Lake, Alta.

In accordance with your instructions I left Calgary by train on Jan'y 2nd, arriving at Driftpile at 3.30 A.M. On the 3rd, I was met by Mr. N.L'Heureux, Indian Agent, who drove me to his home.

At 1.30 P.M., Jan. 3rd, we left Driftpile by sleigh for Whitefish Lake. Mr. L'Heureux, who accompanied me, had made preparations in advance, and we occupied a "caboose" mounted on bob-sleighs, in which were placed a small sheet-iron stove, fuel, provisions and bedding. We were driven by Charlie Anderson, the Agency Interpreter. The temperature was 24 degrees below zero, with 18" of snow.

We proceeded by way of Grouard, crossing Lesser Slave Lake on the ice, and reaching Grouard at 6.30 PM after a drive of 26 miles, where we were kindly received at the R.C.Mission where we spent the night.

Leaving Grouard Mission at 8 AM of the 4th, we drove all day through a rough bush country, breaking the trail through the snow, and at 6 PM stopping for the night about 25 miles from Grouard, and about 16 miles from our destination. We slept in the caboose, with an outside temperature of 35 below zero. Starting again at 8 AM of the 5th (Sunday) we reached St. Andrew's Anglican Mission at 11 AM of the same day. Our journey of approximately 70 miles occupied 2 days, or 17 hours of actual travelling time.

The Rev. C.D. White, Principal, received us kindly, and put us up for the remainder of the day, and overnight. On Monday morning, the 7th Jan'y, in a temperature of 54 degrees below zero, and through 18" of snow, he conducted us to his choice of site for the proposed new school. This site is about 150 yds to the rear of the existing mission buildings, and distant about 300 yds from the lake, with an elevation of about 10 ft above the lake level, being on the crest of a fair sized knoll, with the land sloping away in all directions. It impressed me as being a suitable building site, high and dry, with good drainage facilities, and facing the lake with a S.W. outlook. I have indicated the site in pencil, shown on Lot 4, English Church Mission Plot, Plan of Atikamisis Lake Settlement, enclosed herewith. A little land clearing will be necessary in removing trees. I enclose a snap-shot of the site.
With regard to a water-supply for the proposed school, there are 2 existing sources of supply—one the lake itself, and the other being Minx River. The Rev. Prin. states that the latter is much the better water, particularly in the summer. I asked him to guide me in the most direct route from the building site to the nearest point on the river, which he undertook to do, following his usual trail through deep snow and dense bush, past two Indian cemeteries, then through thick brush, until I fancied we were both lost! Finally we emerged beside an Indian's shack fronting on the river, and guarded by threatening huskies. I had attempted to pace the distance as I followed my guide, but the travelling was so circuitous that I could not get up, and I'm sure a water-line trench is impracticable in that direction, and the distance too great, probably nearly half a mile.

The 2nd existing source of water-supply (from the lake) is much more feasible, but would require about 350 yds. of pipe and a 7 ft. trench across land already cleared. As the lake is shallow near the shore it might be necessary to sink a well near the shore to a depth well below the bottom of the lake ice, and to take the water from such well the lake water should enter the well freely through sand and gravel, and be filtered to some extent at the same time. A small well-house and pumping plant could be built over the suggested well when proven, and the water forced to a pressure-tank or reservoir at the school.

A 3rd possibility for a water-supply would be to dig a well at or near the site, and if a suitable supply could be obtained in this way it would prove less costly than taking it from the lake. As well-digging rigs are not available in that region, any well would have to be dug. It might prove worth while to try this chance first.

Sand and gravel, especially sand, are said to be procurable at no great distance from the mission. Local inquiries resulted in a tug of gravel being brought for my examination by a half-breed who had dug it with pick and shovel from frozen ground on our own place. The sample, though rather dirty from surface soil, indicated gravel suitable for concrete, and as it was said to be from a large body, I think we may safely assume that sufficient sand and gravel are available not far from the proposed site. Owing to the extreme low temperature and deep snow I did not prospect for sand and gravel myself, but had to depend on local information in this regard.

As coal is not available at Whitefish Lake, but an unlimited supply of wood in the adjoining bush, the heating boilers would require to be wood-burning. The trees in the locality are mostly poplar, with a scattering of fir and other conifers. Perhaps two moderate-sized boilers might be preferable to one large boiler, and easier transported.

The existing buildings at St. Andrew's Mission are unpretentious one-storey log structures with attics above, and somewhat dilapidated in appearance. About 25 young Indian children were in residence, and the small staff of five appeared to be carrying on courageously under adverse conditions, and with no modern conveniences to mitigate their hardships, the children were well-behaved, and everything seemed to be running smoothly and harmoniously in the work of this remote mission on the fringe of civilization.

Transportation is a very important factor in connection with any building programme at Whitefish Lake. Roads, as generally understood, are non-existent, there being only ungraded trails winding through the bush, often over muskeg surfaces. It is said that summer hauling over the muskegs...
between Lesser Slave and Whitefish Lakes is impossible, and that all heavy hauling must be done during the winter months if at all. Such being the case it would seem imperative that if a modern school is to be built this year at Whitefish Lake then the promptest possible action must be taken to get the building materials delivered before the spring break-up, which I am told usually occurs about the end of March, occasionally a little later.

Mr. L'Heureux assures me he can get sufficient Indians and their teams to do the hauling, and that a number of them are already keeping their horses fed so as to have them in good shape for this undertaking when he says the hauling will give them a chance to earn some much-needed cash, and that he would like it awarded only to Indians, and not to white men with other sources of relief. From the railway to Whitefish Lake will take 4 days for the round trip, and assuming 200 lbs to a load, the hauling cost will probably run to about $14.00 a ton. This estimate is on the basis of $6.00 a day for man and team, from which they would have to find their own hay, oats, food and shelter.

Regarding the route to be followed in hauling materials from the railway to Whitefish Lake, one alternative would be to unload at Grouard station (marked Emile on old maps) then haul the 14 miles to Grouard R.C. Mission, then 40 miles through the bush to destination; this route avoids crossing Lesser Slave Lake, which is sometimes precarious. Another alternative being investigated by Mr. L'Heureux is to unload at Driftmile station adjoining the Agency, then haul direct north, crossing Lesser Slave Lake, then continuing northward through the bush over an old trail not used for some years, and which will require opening up again should this route be found feasible. It would shorten the haul somewhat, and the unloading from the railway, and the spreading out of the teams, could be more readily supervised. The drawback would be the crossing of Lesser Slave Lake, even if the trail itself through the bush were found practicable. Mr. L'Heureux intends making a thorough examination of the possibilities of this alternative route, and will report his findings to me at an early date. The cost of hauling would probably be the same by either route.

If it is the Department's intention to build the school this year I shall make bold to offer respectfully a few suggestions for consideration, because of the urgency of early building, and to avoid the delay incidental to the advertising for tenders and the awarding of a contract, I would suggest either that a reliable contractor be nominated by the Department to carry out the work on a contract basis as "cost plus", under Departmental supervision; or that the work be done by day-labour under the direction of a building inspector of the Department. I would further suggest that a car of lumber, roofing paper, nails, stoves, etc., be delivered at an early date so that a bunk-house, mess-house and storage shed could be built in advance, and a working camp established in readiness for occupancy. Whitefish Lake is an isolated place, and all necessary facilities will have to be provided from the outside.

All the foregoing is respectfully submitted.

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

Ottawa, March 26, 1936.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant, requesting to be informed if funds will be available for the erection of a new residential school building at Whitefish Lake during the coming fiscal year.

In reply I have to say that definite instructions have been issued by the Treasury Board for a drastic cut in our Appropriation. Therefore, the amount that was included for the erection of new buildings had to be deleted. Our Estimates have now been passed by Parliament.

I may add that it is understood the Government intends to provide an appropriation under the Public Works Construction Act. The Department is endeavouring to obtain, from this appropriation, sufficient funds to purchase the materials required in the construction of a building at Whitefish Lake, in order that delivery can be made at the site, by next winter's freight. At the present time, I am not in a position to advise whether the funds to commence the work at this school will be provided. The Department regrets very much that it was necessary to greatly reduce the appropriation for the carrying out of its educational work during the coming fiscal year. It may be the middle of May before we will be definitely aware as to the appropriation that will be available for new buildings, including the school at Whitefish Lake.

Yours truly,

White, Principal of our White Fish Lake School, writing on the 6th inst., states that he had not received any grant for the Night Watchman's salary, and as the man greatly needed the money he was paying it from his own personal funds. As you stated in your letter of Oct. 10th last No. 150-53, that payment of the grant would be made monthly to the Principal, I am unable to understand the delay in remitting the same to Mr. White.

Mr. White enclosed with his letter to me the following copy of a letter he had just received from Mr. Indian Agent L'Heureux:

Dear Sir: Dec. 31, 1936

As requested by the Department I beg to inform you that the grant towards the salary of a night watchman will be continued to your school at the rate of $40.00 per month commencing the 1st of October.

Voucher is being passed today for payment of the first quarter.

N.P. L'Heureux,

This letter appears to me to require some comment: (1) Why did the Indian Agent delay until Dec. 31st to inform Mr. White of the availability of a grant from the 1st of October. (2) Why does he state that a voucher is being passed for payment for the first quarter, when your letter stated distinctly that payment would be made monthly.
As the delay in remitting to Mr. White the Night Watchman's salary has caused him much inconvenience I shall be obliged if you will take the matter up with your local representative and arrange, so far as possible, for prompter payment of this agent's salary in the future.

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:-

On November 16, 1937, Mr. Indian Agent L'Heureux, of Driftpile, Alta., wrote to the Reverend R.T. Cathcart, Principal of our St. Andrew's School at White Fish Lake, Alta., stating that you had granted authority for the expenditure of $500.00 for enlarging the sleeping quarters at this School.

It would appear that when this authority was requested a list of the materials required was submitted in a letter dated October 22nd, and it was the expectation of the Principal that he himself would be allowed to purchase the material and to engage the necessary labour. It would also appear that the Principal reckoned that the grant authorized would cover all expenditures involved.

The Principal found, however, that practically all of the grant was spent on the materials which were purchased by the Indian Agent, and he applied to our Commission for supplementary grants amounting to $20.00 for labour. As the Commission did not have all the facts of the case before them at that time they sanctioned this expenditure, but since receiving the following additional information they feel justified in requesting your branch of Government to reimburse them to that extent:-

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volu, e 6380, file 769-5, part 2)
Writing on June 9th last, the Principal states, in part, as follows:

"Following the grant by the Indian Department of $500.00, I worked out with great care and with the help of three others, the cost of this new building and the materials required. I was certainly under the impression that the right of spending the grant would be given to me as it was with the late Rev. C.D. White, upon the issuing of a detailed account of the requirements. However, in the same letter that I received notification of the grant having been made it was also stated that everything had been purchased and was on its way into the School. I had not counted upon that in my estimates because I knew I could get the freighting done for less, apart from the fact that those in this place were more entitled to the business than outsiders. Out of the $500.00 grant $140.00 was spent in freighting in five or six loads of lumber, etc. I also ordered 3000 ft. of rough lumber and 1000 ft. of dressed, but the Indian Agent sent me 4000 ft. of shiplap. He paid in this one item $7.00 more per thousand feet and also paid for freighting it in from Driftville, 70 miles further away than was necessary, as we have a sawmill only 30 miles away. The whole thing was simply this that his own friends obtained the business regardless of extra cost at the expense of St. Andrew's Mission. The money I expected to spend on the logs went into the wrong kind of lumber and freighting. He spent all of the $500.00 except $35.00 which went towards the cost of landing the logs here ......... because of the Indian Agent's handling of the $500.00 I cannot complete the building with less than $125.00 from the Commission, to be spent chiefly on labour".

On December 6th, 1937, our Commission authorized an expenditure for labour of $100.00, and again on July 16th of the current year, 1938, they authorized a further expenditure of $120.00, making a total authorized expenditure of $220.00.

As it appears to be quite clear from the above statement of the Principal that this additional expenditure on the part of the Commission would not have been necessary had he been allowed to purchase the material or had the Indian Agent purchased it in the most economical way, the Commission feel justified in asking that they be
reimbursed to the extent specified, and we will be obliged if you will furnish us with your cheque for that amount.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary of the Commission.

TBRW/KH

Dear Sir,

Please find enclosed the (Return of Labour sheets) filled in and signed by the two carpenters who worked on the building from the week ending Aug. 6th. to Oct. 1st. Together they worked a total of 660 hours at 25¢ per hour making a total of $220.00. This, I believe covers the information requested in your letter of Oct. 27th. to Dr. Westgate of the C. of E. Indian & Residential School Commission.

May I take this opportunity of thanking you most sincerely for this grant. It has made it possible to give each child a separate bed and already we have noticed a marked difference in their general health and conduct, as practically every child was sleeping with another and this did not give either the proper rest that is obtained when sleeping alone. As a Staff, it is enabling us to do a more satisfactory and efficient work with the children in the meantime, until a new School is erected to replace the present one of logs, very old and worn out through long years of Service to this Reserve.

Again thanking you for this timely assistance and with the best of Christmas Greetings,

I remain,

Sir,

Herewith please find Requisition in duplicate for school material for the Whitefish Lake C.E. Residential School of Atikameg.

The supply of same complete is recommended; the establishment of the library books for supplementary reading is desirable.

I refer to the items: One Union Jack, 6 Pyrene Fire Extinguishers with 12 refills as shown on the last page of the requisition. These were not promised by me as indicated but I promised I would recommend the supply. The flag has been an oft-repeated item in this school's previous requisitions. As best as I can remember it dates back three years when the initial demand was made. As to the fire extinguishers, I quote from my treaty notes:

"Rev. Principal inquires for Union Jack and for Fire Extinguishers. Asked him to submit requisition on sheet separate from that for school material. - Allowance for fire extinguishers could be reduced to one for every 325 sq. ft of room as buildings are of logs, very old and are regular fire neat although they are kept in good state of maintenance.- Had two small fires during last two years; one burned area 5' x 5' in roof before it could be reached; cause not told. Type best suited could be the soda an acid type, size 2 gallons although for easy manipulation by children some of Pyrene pump type could be supplied. Fire drills should be held evry 3 months. Fire escapes should be clear from obstructions."

The quantity of extinguishers requisitioned, I find, is insufficient and I am communicating again with the Rev. Principal on this subject. In the meantime I would recommend the supply of those requisitioned.

Yours very truly,

N. P. L'Heureux
Indian Agent.
