St Andrew's Indian Resid. School,
Atikameg, Alberta,
September 14th, 1939.

Mr. H. P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent,
Driftpile, Alta.

Dear Sir,

During your visit to this school last November and on June 5th last (Treaty Day) in company with Mr. C. Pant. Schmidt, the Superintendent for the Province, when we pointed out the urgent need for buildings and repairs to the present buildings for our stock and the need of a building for our implements, wagons, sleighs, etc. In the history of the school there has never been such a building or anywhere to put the said articles. In the training of the children in the care of stock and equipment, I feel it is very necessary to give them an object lesson, in the place where they are being trained for the future. Our cow barn is forty years old and being of logs is rotten and dangerous to work in and at a rather dangerous angle. Last winter we had one of the animals partly frozen because it is impossible to keep it warm in our severe winters. The shingling of the roofs and the replacement of new logs under the other buildings along with lumber to put in the lofts for flooring in order to hold hay and new planking and runners for the barns will cost about $500.00

These were pointed out to you both in your visit and I was assured that everything possible would be done to see that the need was met as the above mentioned repairs and replacements were of a certainty badly needed. I am not sure whether they will be or costly. It is, in my humble opinion, much more important to have buildings and equipment such as they can copy upon graduation, and not such that it will be forever impossible for them to duplicate. Thus I feel that if I can have buildings well built of logs, carefully plastered so as to be warm and comfortable and keep the stock in the best that stock ought to be kept and cared for then the children will be given such a practical object lesson which will remain with them through life. All the tools and implements set into these people are never cared for but are left out in all kinds of weather and wherever they finish working. One sees them frozen in on the side of the lake and lying stripped of parts wherever their hayfields are located. This summer when going through the bush, parts of mowers were picked up in several places by the Farm Instructor. If this situation is not to be remedied and the children trained that are growing up, then this is the place and the only one where it will be done. You will I am sure help me out in this and give me the assistance and co-operation necessary to put it into effect. Personally you will lift a very real load off my shoulders by the granting of the above and I know that in a like manner it will be deeply appreciated by the Commission who are absolutely unable to make the replacements. We have at the present time two carpenters at the Mission working on the church with funds raised in England and if you could forward this request and need to the Department for their sanction so that I could have these do the work before they leave as the work is badly needed before the cold weather sets in. Would you help me out in this matter by your immediate attention and let me know the results in the very near future. I would be most grateful and we could get a splendid job done by the carpenters at a reduced cost. Their work with the Church will be finished in about a month.

Enclosed you will find the estimates in detail and I am forwarding a copy as I mentioned at Treaty time to Mr. Schmidt's Office. Thanking you for past favours and in appreciation of your interests in our needs at this Mission. I might mention in closing that I obtained a permit for lumber cutting which will cover our
needs, at a saving of $3.00 per thousand ft. Mr Myles is cutting it for the church at present time. Again thanking you, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) Robt. T. Cathcart
Principal.

Calgary, October 17th, 1939.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith copy of communication received from Mr. N.P. L'Heureux, Indian Agent, Lesser Slave Lake Agency, with copy of a letter and requisition Form 37 received by him from Rev. R. T. Cathcart, Principal, St. Andrew's Residential School, Atikameg, attached. I am also enclosing copy of a letter addressed to myself by the Reverend Principal.

When at this Reserve and school last June, I remarked to both the Agent and the Principal that it was regrettable that the buildings had been let go so long without repairs, and asked the Reverend Principal to make a formal request, through the Agent's office, that this work be carried out this year.

As it is, all I can say is, that these buildings are in dire need of repair: I appreciate the Principal's remark that the granting of this request will lift a very real load off his shoulders, insomuch as he states that the Commission (Church) are absolutely unable to make the replacements.

The Principal does not state the rate of wages he intends paying for carpenters. The amount of $213.00 seems to me to be rather high.

As regards freighting material from High Prairie and Salt Prairie to Atikameg, the School have no horses fit for this work; the only horses they have are a very, very old team used for chores around the place.

I would ask the Department to give this requisition their kind and just consideration, and recommend that the request be granted, purchases of material to be made locally.

Your obedient servant,

C. Fant. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter dated the 30th ultimo from Rt. Rev. Arthur H. Sovereign, Bishop of Athabasca, in which he states that urgent repairs are required at both the Wabasca C.E. and Whitefish Lake C.E. Residential Schools.

At the Wabasca C.E. School he states that $300.00 is required for labour and $200.00 for material. Funds are available for this purpose and I should appreciate your advising me immediately what material is needed in order that purchase may be made through our Purchasing Branch. In regard to the labour, you should let me know if Indian labour is to be employed, but if white labour is required you should state definitely the tradesmen needed.

An amount of $450.00 is also available for repairs and improvements at the Whitefish Lake Indian Residential School. You should supply, at once, similar information as requested in the case of the Wabasca C.E. School; namely, detailed information regarding the material in order that purchase may be made through our Purchasing Branch and also information regarding the labour.

Yours truly,

Mr. N. P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent,
Driftpile, Alta.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Mr. N.F. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent,
Driftpile, Alberta.

Dear Sir:

Please find the estimates below for the Grant of $450.00 recently allocated to the above School.

The buildings upon which the repairs are to be made are as follows—

The Principal's Residence—
The Residential School—
The School store house—
The new cow barn which was formerly underestimated as to the cost. This additional grant will complete the same. In order to save the foundation logs, I wish to put cement pillars under it, which will add to the life by many years of the foundation logs apart from the preventing of such a large building from constantly rising and falling from the winter and summer thawing and freezing.

We are employing as much Indian labour as we can possibly do in any work done that they are capable of doing. I am only letting those work who have had previous experience. We cannot afford to pay for their training. We have living here at Whitefish lake a former Far-Instructor who is a good carpenter and tin-smith. He is far more reasonable in his charges than anyone we could obtain from outside, to do the same work and do it as well.

Shingling of the Residence roof completely and of the School Residence repairs here and there where it is in bad shape. The Principal's Resid. has not been done for nearly forty years and is leaking in several places.

New logs are being put around all the buildings except the School (day school) on the foundation because in the majority of the buildings they were rotten up to the second log and the buildings were sinking to a dangerous angle. The plastering has to be replaced by the fact of the moving of the logs in raising the said buildings.

In a letter to the Govt. re the fire protection of the above School you made the Statement after an Inspection here with Mr. Schmidt, that it was a fire trap but that all the precautions possible were being taken. This grant has enabled us to put asbestos and tan around every one of the places where the stove pipes pass through a floor, and to put in an escape for the girls dormitory in case of fire apart from the stairway. In other words with the additional fire sprays granted last year, we have everything as safe for the children as it is humanly possible to make it in a log building.

WINNIPEG, MAN. July 30, 1943.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

St. Andrew's Indian Residential School,
Whitefish Lake

The Rev. R. T. Cathcart, Principal of the above school, has long experienced considerable difficulty in securing and retaining his staff under the present cramped living accommodation. As you know, the building is old and we are advised that the living quarters are so inadequate that it has even been necessary to ask the Matron to occupy a room through which a male member of the staff must pass to his own.

We have been striving to secure three lady members for the coming year and have found it exceedingly difficult. The Principal has planned an enlargement of the Laundry portion which would provide an additional room and also make possible a much-needed ice-house. He claims that some of the materials for this work are in hand, but a grant is needed before the work can be done.

The need for such an enlargement is now immediate as we have received an offer from Mrs. S. Hyde, R.N., a former member of the school staff, who is willing to return as Matron and District Nurse. The Principal is delighted at the prospect of having Nurse Hyde back and declares that she is "as near to the perfect Matron as any Principal could desire". He states, however, that the proposed enlargement is essential for her and the invalid husband who must accompany her. He is, therefore, anxious that the work shall be put in hand in order that he may be able to obtain the services of a valuable worker who will be likely to remain at the school for years to come. He estimates that the cost of the work will be not more than $450.00 and asks us to approach your Department with the request for a special grant.
The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, - 2. July 30, 1943.

Knowing the real inadequacy of the present building and the extreme difficulty of securing a qualified Nurse under present conditions, we strongly endorse the request and trust that your Department may be able to consider it favourably.

Thanking you, I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary.

Dear Sir:

I have been requested by the Indian Agent—Mr. Demars—to write to you for sanction re the spending of the $400.00 grant upon labour alone. There were so many repairs made to the above School this year in the effort to make it more warm and comfortable for the children and staff that it cost far more than the amount granted and I felt that the least trouble for all concerned would be to make it out for labour. This last summer we had three carpenters working on a Church and Community Mission Hall—(paid for by friends of the Mission in this country and in the Old Land) and as the floors on our Laundry and children's dining room were quite rotten in parts from over 45 years of service I had them replaced as well as some insulation work to other parts as the Staff on duty in the Staff Room at nights, during the winter time often have to wear their overcoats despite a roaring fire. What material I did not have on hand for this work from last year I supplied from that of the Church and Hall as I might not be fortunate enough to get any help again for some time and I had to act immediately as we so very often have to do in these isolated places. Both in labour and material the sum spent was double the grant, therefore if the Dept. makes the grant for labour I will forward the Labour Returns to the Agent upon receipt of your confirmation. It is a very difficult time to obtain help in the se isolated Schools and it is certainly made no easier for me or the Commission when living conditions are what they are here in a building long overdue in repairs. True we have been doing a little every year since the new School promised has failed to materialize but dragging it out a little each year is a very tiresome job and a hindrance to the best in efficiency and good work. It has meant that during the last seven years I have been tied down to this repair work each summer while the children were away and have paid my share in no holidays. Your attention and kindness to this matter will be appreciated and I will look forward to hearing from you in the very near future.

The above $400.00 grant is for the year 1944. Mr. Demars in a recent inspection approved the said repairs made and suggested others necessary in the very near future. Thanking you, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

The Principal points out, however, that, since these estimates were originally submitted by him to your local Agent, the addition to the present day-school building has increased the roof area by some 800 square feet which would increase the roofing estimate by about 15% or, say, $180.00.

I again suggest that the balance of $693.40 on your 1948-49 appropriation for this school (see my letter of 17th September, 1948) be used for the purchase of as much of the roofing materials as possible and that the balance required be provided in your Departmental Estimates 1949-50 in addition to the services listed in my letter "Est. 1949-50" of 17th September, 1948.

Superintendent
Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed the approximate estimates for the Asbestos roofing, and the keeping of meat and fish through the summer months, necessitates an ice house being built and also a fire escape for the girls' dormitory. These were mentioned to you in your recent visit to the School and you agreed as to the urgent need of the same. We have already had a number of fires from the old wooden shingles, some of which have been on for over forty years. I am enclosing a snap of the last one - the roof being only temporarily fixed for the present. I feel a constant weight in worry over the same and our vigilence has no peace or rest from one year to another, and I feel that some day one of these roof fires will get too much of a start to save the School. The urgent request for the replacements is being made through you to the Indian Dept. at Ottawa.

In reference to tin roofs or galv. iron - I may state that I am requesting Asbestos as more durable and satisfactory in every respect. The winds from the lake are terrific at times and metal roofs have proven to be no end of trouble in becoming loose apart from their noise from rain and heat in summer. The Manager of the Gov. Hatchery at Canyon Creek, has stated to me that they have never proven satisfactory at any time. The same trouble would be ours. Asbestos roofing if properly put on is also 90% good for future use if removed.

Re: The ice house - the present one has been in use for fifty years, and as it is built of logs, you will understand that its usefulness has long since passed. It is in danger of collapsing at any time.

Re: Fire escape - one can be installed here that will be satisfactory.

Re: Repairs to Anglican Residential School - Whitefish Lake

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter of September 29, file 131-10-5 (E.1).

Attached please find requisition for supplies for repairs of the roofs at the Anglican Residential School at Whitefish Lake. The requisition also covers the building of a fire-escape for the Girl's Dormitory.

During my recent visit to Whitefish Lake I examined the buildings at the Anglican Residential School. Those buildings are built of logs and are very inadequate from the standpoint of sanitation and fire prevention, and are very unattractive in appearance. There is no plumbing, no water pressure system and the buildings are heated with outdated stoves.

Although I have placed my signature on the requisition for supplies, I am of the opinion that the expense involved in making repairs to the roofs of the existing buildings is unwarranted. I would recommend that the fire escape for the Girl's Dormitory be constructed immediately.

G.S. Lapp
Superintendent.

Whitefish Lake Residential School

The above Residential School is situated at Atikameg in northern Alberta. It has been operated in old buildings, many of them of log construction and presenting a definite fire hazard. Two years ago it was found that the school still used oil and gasoline lanterns and was heated with small stoves.

It had only a pupilage of 30 and was operated by the Indian School Administration of the M.S.C.C.

As a result of an educational survey, it was decided, with the agreement of the M.S.C.C., to take the following action:

(a) Erect a new dormitory block at the Wabasca Anglican Residential School situated in the same agency, which would provide safe accommodation for the children at both Wabasca and at Whitefish Lake who required institutional care;

(b) To erect a two-room day school at Whitefish Lake for the Protestant children living there (we already have a Catholic day school at Atikameg - which is the Indian word for Whitefish Lake).

I attach a series of photographs which will give you a factual presentation of the school as it existed. The photographs are numbered as follows:

1. The residential school classroom is at the left with the teachers' living quarters in the next log building.
2. The community hall.
3. The community hall from another angle.
4. Interior of the community hall, showing finishing materials.
5. Interior of classroom.
6. Teacher and "white" children - these are really half-breeds and we are corresponding with the Alberta Department of Education concerning a joint school for them.
7. Chief and Councillors.
8. Atikameg R. C. School, - erected by Department three years ago.

I would recommend the Minister's approval of the following action:

(a) The closing of the Whitefish Lake Residential School as of June 30, 1950.

(b) The opening, in temporary quarters, of the Whitefish Lake Indian Day School as of 1 September, 1950.

(c) The continuance of negotiations with the Alberta Department of Education for the operation of a joint school at this point. (Our Educational Survey Officer will soon be leaving for the West).

Encl.

Recommended: Deputy Minister.

Approved: Minister.

Dear Mr. Clark,

Thanks so much for your letter of June 18th received today re: Whitefish Lake.

I am so pleased that you were able to visit the area for I know how interested you are and how helpful you have been to our Indian Wards.

I believe that a two-roomed Day School is what is needed now at Whitefish Lake and I think that Miss Powell and Miss Wright would be two excellent teachers. As you so wisely suggest, I believe that some arrangement between the two Governments can be made for we are all interested mutually in the education and training of our Indian and those with Indian blood in their veins. I trust that your views as expressed in your letter may be carried out.

I also hope that real progress may be made quickly and that if at all possible the two-roomed school could be completed this year. The need is great and time is passing.

I know that it is the intention of both the Provincial and Federal Governments that all children in Canada, especially those of our Indian Wards should receive a real training so that they may become good Canadian citizens. You will be interest to know that at our Diocesan Synod held last week a resolution was passed in which special thanks were to be sent to the Department of Indian Affairs for their sympathetic assistance and wise administration. May I again thank you for your kind help.

With every good wish, and with many thanks,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Whitefish Lake Residential School

The above Residential School is situated at Atikameg in northern Alberta. It has been operated in old buildings, many of them of log construction and presenting a definite fire hazard. Two years ago it was found that the school still used oil and gasoline lanterns and was heated with small stoves.

It had only a pupilage of 30 and was operated by the Indian School Administration of the M.S.C.C.

As a result of an educational survey, it was decided, with the agreement of the M.S.C.C., to take the following action:

(a) Erect a new dormitory block at the Wabasca Anglican Residential School situated in the same agency, which would provide safe accommodation for the children at both Wabasca and at Whitefish Lake who required institutional care;

(b) To erect a two-room day school at Whitefish Lake for the Protestant children living there (we already have a Catholic day school at Atikameg - which is the Indian word for Whitefish Lake).

I attach a series of photographs which will give you a factual presentation of the school as it existed. The photographs are numbered as follows:

1. The residential school classroom is at the left with the teachers' living quarters in the next log building.
2. The community hall.
3. The community hall from another angle.
4. Interior of the community hall, showing finishing materials.
5. Interior of classrooms.
6. Teacher and "white" children - these are really half-breeds and we are corresponding with the Alberta Department of Education concerning a joint school for them.
7. Chief and Councillors.
8. Atikameg R.C. School, - erected by Department three years ago.

I would recommend the Minister's approval of the following action:

(a) The closing of the Whitefish Lake Residential School as of June 30, 1950.

(b) The opening, in temporary quarters, of the Whitefish Lake Indian Day School as of 1 September, 1950.

(c) The continuance of negotiations with the Alberta Department of Education for the operation of a joint school at this point. (Our Educational Survey Officer will soon be leaving for the West).

Director.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Further to your letter of March 20th 1950.

Upon receipt of the above mentioned letter from your office a copy of same was forwarded to Principal Johnston and today we received the enclosed letter (copy) from him. It would appear that Mr. Lapp was rather indifferent about the whole affair and lax in his efforts to locate the stove.

Your letter of the 21st ultimo comes as a surprise to me, and I note Mr. Lapp's comments. On the 2nd of August last, Mr. Lapp arrived here with the Treaty Party and I mentioned the Range to him then and he replied that "it would arrive sometime soon". I again saw Mr. Lapp in High Prairie at his office on the 4th of October, and he wondered where the range was. The next occasion I had of seeing Mr. Lapp was when he and the School Supt. had lunch with us here on the 2nd of February and he was at a loss to understand where the range could have disappeared to. We all wondered if it had been delivered to the local R.C. Mission by mistake and he said, "I've no authority to go into the R.C. Mission to see if it is there", so he said "I will make enquiries at Mr. Bill Atkins' home in Salt Prairie to see if it might be there" as Mr. Atkins often brings out freight from Enilda to his home there and keeps it until teams from here go for same, and I suggested that it might be either at Grouard or Wabasca Missions, and he promised to look for same, as he returned home on the evening of the 2nd of February by car in company with the R.C.M.P. Officers, by enquiring at the Atkins' home in Salt Prairie, and the Grouard R.C. Mission and the Enilda N.A.R. Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Hay Fields White Fish Lake

In your letter of May 13th last, No. 131-10-9, you desired me to furnish you with any additional information which Mr. Cathcart, Principal, of our White Fish Lake School, had obtained from the Provincial Government of Alberta about hay fields, other than those handed over to the Metis Colony which has been organized.

For your information I may say that I wrote to the Alberta Government in this matter on May 3, and forwarded a copy of my letter to Dr. McGill, Director of your Department. The enclosed reply was received on May 15th. As it left the matter still undecided I wrote again to Mr. Cathcart and ascertained that he had been able to locate a hay supply about the same distance from the School, but outside the area set apart for the Metis Colony and had forwarded a request to our Bishop of Athabasca (The Right Reverend Dr. A.H. Sovereign) at Peace River, where the Land Office is located, to find out if the School could secure their hay from that source. In this connexion Bishop Sovereign wrote to me as follows on June 23rd last:

"Mr. Cathcart has not been able to get very much satisfaction from the Metis Colony but he has found another area north of the big Whitefish Lake. This is about the same distance from the Mission. I have been down to the Land Office in Peace River to see about it and everything seems fairly clear in regard..."
to it. There were one or two mistakes in his application and I have sent them back for correction and when they are returned next week I hope that the Mission can be supplied for some time to come with sufficient hay for the stock. The representative of the Metis Colony was quite unreasonable in his demands and would only give the lease for one year. When given any authority, they do not seem to know how to use it reasonably."

While it would appear from the above that satisfactory arrangements can be made for securing the hay required, the members of our Commission still feel, as I pointed out in my letter to Dr. McGill on May 3rd, that the land attached to our White Fish Lake School should be increased from the 84 acres it now embodies to at least half a section, and preferably to a whole section.

The Church of England has faithfully served your wards in that part of the country so long that the members feel strongly they are entitled to more consideration than they have hitherto received at this centre in the way of new buildings and other improvements. Most of the buildings, which were put up many years ago with Church funds, are so old and so comfortless that I do not find it easy to offer staff appointments there to any of the numerous applicants who look to me for an opening for service in our Church's Indian Residential School Work.

It has been one of my most earnest desires for some years to see a new school building at White Fish Lake and another at Wabasca, and I would willingly vacate my present position in favour of a younger man if I saw these two most urgent needs supplied.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

Dear Dr. McGill:

In a letter recently received from Rev. R.T. Cathcart, Principal of our Society's Whitefish Lake School in Alberta, he informs me that the Provincial Government of Alberta has established "Metis colony" approximately 9 miles from Whitefish Lake, with "a grant of some thousands of acres of land so that each member that wishes, will receive besides other things such as livestock and implements, and lumber, a grant of a section of land."

The concern of the Principal of our School over the establishment of this colony, centres round the fact that the area includes the hay fields from which his school's supply of hay has been secured through Government permit duly paid for, for many years past.

As these hay fields are practically the only ones in that part from which the hay can be secured, our Society will now be faced with an additional expense in the operation of this school, of approximately $500 a year.

I have written to the Deputy Minister of Mines in the Government of the Province of Alberta to ascertain if some consideration can be extended to the school management for another year or two, or until such time as we are able to secure and clear sufficient land nearer our present school site, and on which the necessary hay and green feed could be grown. As our Whitefish Lake School has only 84 acres attached to it,
it is the opinion of our Commission that this should be increased, and I am writing for the specific purpose of ascertaining if your Branch of Government will secure the increase for us. I have asked the Principal to make a careful examination of the land adjacent to our present school property, and to submit a recommendation as to what land would best be suited from the standpoints of hay and location for the purpose. He will also furnish, so far as he may be able, an estimate of the cost of such land per acre.

Any help which your Branch of Government may be able to give our Society in the way suggested, and under the new and unexpected conditions which have arisen, will be duly appreciated by all concerned.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

The Principal of our Society's Indian Residential School at Whitefish Lake (Atikameg) Alta., the Rev. R.T. Cathcart has informed our Commission in a letter recently received from him, that the Provincial Government of Alberta has set apart some thousands of acres of land for a Metis colony.

Although the colony will be located approximately 9 miles from Atikameg, the Principal of our School is much concerned over the fact that the land area set apart for it includes the hay fields from which his school has theretofore duly secured hay permits, secured its hay supplies for many years past. So far as he knows no other person or organization secured similar permits, and although the establishment of the colony would now appear to be an accomplished fact, he desires to know if any arrangements could possibly be made whereby his school could continue to secure its hay supply from that same source for another year or two, or until such time as our Society would be able to secure sufficient land nearer the school's location, and on which the necessary hay and green feed could be grown.

As Mr. Cathcart expects to visit Edmonton shortly he has been authorised by our Commission to talk the matter over with you personally. I need hardly assure you that any consideration you may be able to extend to us under the new and unexpected conditions which have arisen through the
establishing of the colony in question, will be duly appreciated, not only by Mr. Outhoart and his staff, and our vast Diocese of Athabasca in which our Whitefish Lake School is located, but also by our Commission and by our Society.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

REPORT

Re:

Truant Indian School children—Whitefish Lake Indian Reserve.

I have the honour to report that acting under instructions received from Sergt. Schulz, in charge at Grouard detachment, that I left Grouard with Police detachment team Reg. No's 1780 and 1802 on the 16th inst., on patrol to Whitefish Lake Indian Reservation, Alberta. I was instruct- ed by Sergt. Schulz before leaving Grouard, to ascertain the whereabouts of an Indian school boy, by name Julien Hear, age fourteen, this boy being registered at St. Peter's Anglican School at Grouard and having failed to attend this school since its reopening on August 15th last; I was also instructed to visit the St. Andrews Anglican School at Whitefish Lake and interview the Principal in charge as to the attendance of Indian school children there.

I arrived at Whitefish Lake on the 16th inst. From enquiries made there, I learned that the Indian school boy, Julien Hear, was away with his people, presumably somewhere in the vicinity of Big Lake, about fifty miles from Whitefish Lake; as there was no means of locating this boy and interviewing his parents, other than by hiring pack horses, and as his whereabouts could not be definitely ascertained, I left a letter with the Indian councillor James Grey, at Whitefish, which he promised to forward to the parents of this boy at the earliest available opportunity; in this note I instructed the parents to send this boy to school as soon as possible.

On the 17th Sept., I visited the St. Andrews Anglican School at Whitefish and interviewed the Rev. C. D. White, Principal in charge; Mr. White informed me that at present there were fourteen children of Indian parentage attending this school, the average attendance being about nineteen pupils each year; there were four children not attending school, one being sick, and the other three away at summer points from Whitefish; the latter were expected to return shortly, Mr. White stating that he was assured of their attendance at school upon their return, and that he had never had any trouble in this respect.

I left Whitefish Lake with Police team on the 18th inst. for Grouard, arriving at Grouard detachment on the 20th Sept.; throughout this patrol the roads were in an almost impassable condition due to recent heavy rains in this part of the country.

Dear Sir:

The Rev. C. D. White, Principal of our St. Andrew's School at White Fish Lake, Alta., informs me in a letter dated the 16th inst. that the two pupils - Pat Williers (No. 98) and Fleming Williers (No. 0106) who were in residence last year did not return to the school when term opened this last fall.

When our St. Peter's School at Grouard was closed these pupils along with the others then enrolled were transferred to our St. Andrew's School by order of your Inspector Christianson. Their parents brought them to our St. Andrew's School on September 24th, 1932, and the quarterly returns from that date show that they spent the following days in residence:

| Quarter | Name          | Days |
|---------|---------------|------|
| Sept. Qr. 1932 | Pat Williers   | 5    |
|         | Fleming Williers | 5    |
| Dec. Qr. 1932 | Pat Williers   | 60   |
|         | Fleming Williers | 52   |
| March Qr. 1933 | Pat Williers   | 63   |
|         | Fleming Williers | 49   |
| June Qr. 1933 | Pat Williers   | 48   |
|         | Fleming Williers | 43   |
| Sept. Qr. 1933 | Pat Williers   | 43   |
|         | Fleming Williers | 43   |

The Rev. Principal White states that he applied three times to Mr. Indian Agent L'Heureux to have these pupils returned, and that his first two letters were ignored. In reply
to his third letter he states he was informed "the mother claims that it is too far to send her children to White Fish Lake School." His concern over the non-return of these pupils, and over the failure of the local Indian Agent to reply to his first two letters is intensified by information he had received that these pupils "were actually in St. Bruno's R.C. School."

Some years ago your Department ruled that pupils who had begun their education in one school should not be transferred to another school, and as the two pupils in question were first enrolled at our St. Peter's School, and then transferred, by order of your Inspector to St. Andrew's School when St. Peter's School was closed, I can see no reason whatever why they should not be obliged to return at once to that institution.

If they are still at home the mother's reason for not returning them on account of the distance, can hardly be accepted as the school has four other Willier children in residence who come from a greater distance. These are John William No. 100; George Joseph No. 106; Agnes no. 0107; and Clara No. 0108.

If they have been admitted to the St. Bruno R. C. School, an order should be given immediately for their transfer to the St. Andrew's School where they rightly belong, and steps taken to fully establish responsibility for their delay in returning at the appointed time.

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Sir:

With reference to your letters No. 131-10-10 dated January the 25th and April the 9th regarding the removal of George Joseph Willier (Anderson) from the Whitefish Lake Residential school.

I beg to state that when the December Quarterly Return of the Whitefish Lake Residential school was received at this office, three new pupils appeared on the list No. 100 Frank Nehachick No. 106 George Willier No. 108 Edith Keyespapamato. No application form and health certificates were received for them, there being no medical officer in the vicinity of Whitefish Lake, so I wrote to the Reverend Principal and advised him that Dr. McIntrye would visit Whitefish Lake around the beginning of February and to be kind enough to submit the certificates of health of Frank Nehachick and Edith Keyespapamato as soon as possible after the Doctor's visit.

As for George Joseph Willier (Anderson), at the request of his mother, I asked the Rev. G. D. White to release the boy from the school and let him come home with Dr. McIntrye as the child was a Catholic and not eligible for admission to a Church of England School. The mother and also the children of this family are Roman Catholic, but two of the children who are at present attending the Whitefish Lake C. of E. Residential School were re-baptized under Church of England rite for the purpose of acquiring eligibility to that school. The father states that he belongs to the Church of England but apparently he professes no faith whatever.

Dear Sir,

In answer to your letter dated June 15 regarding Indian children in our Residential School who are 16 years and over, asking me to give an explanation why they are kept (noted your letter 1-1-10 top of page c.150-40 bottom).

I am sorry I did not answer this sooner, but I was absent from here attending our Diocesan Synod.

I will as you request take each child separately. 078 North Yellowknife over 16 years, this girl was orphaned, I am her guardian at the wish of her mother. She is an Indian agent at Driftville N.P. & Hurren and I would certainly like to keep her until 18 years of age, I have no place to send her.

073 Elizabeth Bone over 16 her father and mother who live here were very anxious to have her stay at school as her father never went wrong before she got married, not in the school.

0106 Fleming Willie, 17 is a very nice girl comes from Baker Creek close to Driftville. She is with a younger brother here, her older brother is away by way of work after leaving school (the parents to blame) her father was anxious for her to come for her own sake and with her younger brother (this only son).

0107 Agnes Willie from Driftville 17 is with a younger sister here, both her parents were anxious for her to come. I know her and she needs to be guarded.

Being an old missionary having worked for 37 years amongst these people particularly among the young, I see more and more, the necessity of guarding these young girls against evil and keeping them until 18 years of age when they are wiser and have a more settled mind and can be married.

My earnest desire is that they should grow up good and useful citizens of this land and our people. There are now more particular that they should be guarded against evil.

I trust you will approve of my explanation.

Yours very respectfully,

[Signature]

Ottawa, January 20, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of the December quarter return of the Whitefish Lake (St. Andrew's) Indian Residential School.

This return contains the names of the following pupils, for whom no applications for admission or certificates of health have been received:

- No. 114 - Albert Laboucan,
- 115 - Philip Lamouche,
- 116 - Peter Keesepapamotos,
- 117 - Charl. Henry Laboucan,
- 118 - James Ervine Thunder,
- 0116 - Florence Nahathik.

There has been considerable correspondence regarding the first named pupil. In a recent letter from the Principal, he states that he cannot send this application until the Doctor examines the pupil. This boy has been in the school since January, 1936, and there does not appear any reason why the application for him was not forwarded. In the event of delay in the doctor examining new pupils entering a school, the application should be forwarded and the children could be examined later, when the doctor visits the school and a certificate of health forwarded for them.

It is noted, in the case of pupil No. 115, Philip Lamouche, that the religion of the parents is stated to be

N. P. L'Heureux, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Driftpile, Alta.
stated to be Roman Catholic. This child should not have been taken into the school until the application was forwarded, with full particulars, and approval granted. The Department has allowed the grant for the December quarter for this boy but will be unable to allow any further grant until we have full particulars regarding the reasons for taking him into the school. It is considered the Principal should not have admitted this boy until he received the necessary authority.

It is noted, from the return, that five pupils were absent during the entire quarter and no explanation was furnished by the Principal as to the reasons for such absence. In future, when a pupil is absent any part of the quarter, the reason should be stated on the return, in the column for that purpose, opposite the pupil's name.

I would request that you have the Principal prepare and forward applications for all the above mentioned pupils. Full particulars should be given in the case of Philip Lamouche.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

The following letter dated the 19th instant has just been received from the Principal of the Whitefish Lake Indian Residential School:

"Last year about November I wrote to your Indian Agent at Driftpile, N. P. L'Heureux, with regard to one of our boys living at Sucker who had not returned to school, No. 58 - Pat Willier - age 15. When St. Peter's was closed he was transferred to this residential school by orders. I told the agent I was willing to pay all expenses to this school, but I got no answer. I think a polite letter needs an answer of some kind. I also wrote to the parents, but got no answer from them. Since then I have heard that he was put into the R.C. school at Joussard. This kind of thing to me is out of all order, and I feel that it is not just to our school. Your Department authorized the placing of this boy in our school in the year 1932."

Please let me have a report regarding Pat Willier. If he is in the Joussard Residential School, you might let me know his register number.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

N. P. L'Heureux, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Driftpile, Alta.
Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 30th ultimo, your file 131-10-10 with regard to the complaint made by the Principal of Whitefish Lake Indian Residential School about Pat Willier No. 98.

The Principal's letter is dated October 1st and was received here on the 10th. On the 17th I wrote to the boy's parents and sent to the Principal the duplicate copy of the letter without any other form of acknowledgement. I have not received yet a reply from the parents although I again wrote to them on Nov. 5th.

The facts of the case are that the boy's mother, a widow, married Louis John Callio who with his wife, now are recognized as professing the Roman Catholic faith.

The distance from the boy's home to the Whitefish Lake School is of some 40 miles, while the Joussard Residential School is only 8 miles away.

Pat Willier is in the Joussard Residential School but not as a grant-earning pupil. He is there under an arrangement between the boy's step-father and the Principal, presumably at the Mission's expense.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.
In view of the fact that the boy is to reach the statutory age at which he could be discharged from school, I have thought it proper to avoid a dispute with the boy's guardian and have merely asked him in my letter of October 17th, to show cause why the boy should not be in Whitefish Lake Residential, stating however that if he was going to proceed there, his transportation expenses would be paid for by the Principal.

If it is the desire of the Principal of the Whitefish Lake Residential School to press for the boy's return, then I cannot but recommend otherwise and will accede to the father's request for his discharge from the school roll.

Yours faithfully,

N. P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

In Chapter 82 - Part 1 - Section 2 of the Indian Act no Protestant child shall be placed in a Roman Catholic School or Roman Catholic Indian Child in a Protestant School. girls dressed up in the finest of clothes to create

of England has no church, because they have no churches,
no Bible, and that their ministers are igno-
rant and not trained for the work. Furthermore,
he points out the advantages of the new modern
school just built at Atikameg for the Roman Church,
where the children never have to work, as ours do,
and they are not faced by the danger of fire, as
ours is an old building, and lacking in conveniences,
which fails of our aim, but because of sinister
forces at work blocking the grant necessary for a
new building necessary to replace the log ones of
nearly fifty years.

By the giving of quantities of tobacco
and grocerie, he wins the parents of these children
who are the victims of it all. One could keep on
writing about many other things, but enough has been
said to make it clear, just what we are up against
in our attempt to build and mould the spiritual
and moral life of these people. The average indian
is quite susceptible to bribery as you are aware,
and as I refuse to use such methods, because of their
deleterious effects, morally, we lose every year,
three or four children, rescued by the priests, in
the early hours of the morning after a service in
which the children are re-baptized into the (one
true church) as he names.

All I ask, is that the law be upheld and no
child be removed who belongs to our school except by
discharge papers being given to the school from
the Deptt. of Indian Affairs. The existing situation
seems to me to be very near approach to kid-napping
and you will agree with me I am sure, that it is
not a good thing which brings honour to our
British boast of Justice and Fair-play.

During my seven years in this North country
of Yukon and Alberta, I have found the Indians, stand-
ing at all times for Justice and Law mixed with a fine
quality of mercy, but free from any political or re-
ligious affiliations which might destroy the above-
mentioned standards, and I feel certain that my appeal
for assistance in this problem will not go unanswered

This is all I can find out about Helen Mona Grey. I might say that as Joe Cunningham is Emily Grey's husband, Helen lives there a good deal of the time and goes under the name of Cunningham also. I hope this information will be of some help in what you wish for in tracing her through the ticket numbers.

In reference to yours of Jan. 24th re Jack Adams, I cannot obtain information from anyone about whom the parents are. None seems to know or wishes to tell. All I know is that the child was adopted by the grand mother, Louisa Adams, as an infant and raised by her and is on her treaty ticket No. 17. As to having the forms filled in and signed in triplicate I cannot see how that is possible as Prairie Lake is forty miles from here and I am not making that trip every day. The child was sent in by a half-breed and I paid him for his work and also paid him to take one copy of an application form as you only asked for one copy previously. Dear Sir:
Enclosed please find a Requisition for school supplies required by the above School.

A Requisition was sent into your office dated July 5, made out by our former teacher Mr. Fryer. It has been filled but is totally inadequate to in any way meet our needs. Our present teacher Miss K. Courtney has had many years of experience in some of our largest Schools and as all our former teachers were men without certificates from any Normal School, Miss Courtney found on going over the supplies that there were none apart from the few sent in of late. All these years the children have not had what I know is supplied to others by the Department and I feel as I am sure you do also that as we now have a fully qualified teacher it is only fair to her and to the children to have tools to work with which they can now put to the best advantage. I am therefore asking your sympathetic consideration of our needs in order to make our School as efficient as other Schools and as I know the Department wishes it to be. Your earliest attention to this matter will be very greatly appreciated by the Commission, Miss Courtney, and myself.

Thanking you, I remain,

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

Please find attached herewith application from the Principal of Whitefish Lake C. E. Residential School, to keep in residence as grant-earning pupils for a further period beyond the age limit of 16, George Coutre, No. 90 and Gertie Gladu No. 099.

Gertie Gladu suffers from epileptic fits and her return to her family who is destitute and unable to support her properly will not help her towards regaining her health and for this reason I recommend that she remain in school for another year.

Regarding George Coutre, I appreciate what the Principal writes about him. However I am under the impression that the boy's mother will look to him to support her rather than otherwise. Also his work for the mission should be worth at least his board, lodging and clothing if not more. I do not object to him remaining in school longer but would like to see him have something when he goes out of there at the age of 19 or 20. I favor some form of agreement whereby all parties concerned would contribute their share of assistance: the boy by giving his labor, the C. E. Mission by providing for his board, lodging and clothing and the Department by setting aside the per diem school grant earned by the boy until his discharge and using it to purchase stock, cattle, implements or tools of his trade, and with which he can establish himself in life.

I submit this for your consideration.

Yours faithfully,

N. P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Whitefish Lake Residential School

Recently on my visit to the Whitefish Lake Residential School it was found that the only bull in the whole settlement was an Indian Affairs owned animal bearing the name "Charlie". For the past 3-4 years this animal has been retained at the expense of the school but has been used, for breeding purposes, with all the dairy cows in the community. Now there is the danger of in-breeding as "Charlie" is the father of all the young females.

Circumstances indicate that the use of Trumilk and powdered skim-milk is a more economical measure than retaining a herd at this particular school and I am instructing the principal to dispose of his herd. Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Treasury Board, approved by His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the 2nd March, 1949.

The Board had under consideration a memorandum from the Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources reporting:

"THAT funds, to the amount of fifty thousand dollars, are included in the 1949-50 Estimates, Indian Education Vote, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, to commence the construction of a 100 pupilage residential school at Hay Lakes, Fort Vermilion Indian Agency in the Province of Alberta;

THAT the need for a residential school at Hay Lakes has been known for some years and has been established by an educational survey;

THAT it has not been possible to previously plan the erection of this school for these Indians because of its extreme isolation and inaccessibility;

THAT with the completion of the Grimshaw Highway it is now possible to provide transportation by truck to within sixty miles of the school and by tractor train for the remainder of the way;

THAT as these Indians are Roman Catholics, it is intended to operate this residential school under the auspices of this denomination;

THAT the Bishop concerned, through 'La Corporation Episcopale Catholique Romaine de Grouard', has offered to erect this school on a cost basis;

THAT 'La Corporation Episcopale Catholique Romaine de Grouard' has previously erected five church-owned residential schools in Northern Alberta;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C., 1927, provides, in part, as follows:

'Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest.'

THAT it is considered that the construction of this school to provide much needed educational facilities for these very primitive Indians is of pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be expeditiously and economically executed by 'La Corporation Episcopale Catholique Romaine de Grouard', who are familiar with building conditions in isolated and northern areas;

The Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources."
THAT including material, transportation, building costs and unforeseen contingencies the estimated amount required for this building will be approximately one hundred and seventy-five thousand dollars;

THAT if funds are available from any unused appropriation for construction in the 1948-49 Vote Number 218 (Indian Education) authority be granted to purchase part of the materials in order that advantage may be taken of winter freighting facilities which are at least fifty per cent cheaper than summer freight;

THAT in view of the fact that the contractor is a Roman Catholic Episcopal Corporation, a nominal sum acceptable to the undersigned be regarded as good and sufficient security deposit as required by Section 16 (1) of the Public Works Act;

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the expenditure of the funds necessary for the construction of the aforesaid buildings and for the award of a contract to 'La Corporation Episcopale Catholique Romaine de Crouard' of McLennan, Alberta, on the basis of proven cost only of the completed buildings."

The Board concur in the above report and recommendation, and submit the same for favourable consideration.

Clerk of the Privy Council.

The Contractor shall keep proper accounts and records in such form and detail as shall be satisfactory to the Minister of the cost to the Contractor of the work and the invoices, receipts and vouchers relating thereto, and such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers shall at all times be open to audit and inspection by the Minister or his authorized representatives who may make copies thereof and take extracts therefrom, and the Contractor shall furnish all proper facilities for such audits and inspections and shall furnish the Minister and his authorized representative with all such information as he or they may from time to time require with reference to such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers. If any part of the work is performed by an allied firm (as defined herein) the Contractor shall also cause such allied firm to keep similar accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers with respect to the cost of the work performed by such allied firm, and to permit the same to be inspected and audited by the authorized representatives of the Minister. The Contractor shall cause all such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers as aforesaid to be preserved and kept available for audit and inspection at any time and from time to time until the expiration of five (5) years from the date of the termination of the work.

20. WORK TO BE FREE FROM ALL ENCUMBRANCES

Before making any payment on any progress or final estimate the Minister may require the Contractor to furnish evidence that all work performed, and material supplied and all structures built for which payment is made under this contract, are free and clear from all lawful claims or liens under any law for labour, workmanship, materials or otherwise; the Contractor shall indemnify and hold harmless His Majesty from and against any and all kinds of claims or liens accruing from labour and services performed and material furnished or otherwise, and any of the same in or about the works.

21. PATENT CLAIMS AND ROYALTIES

(a) His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent or industrial design rights or of any alleged patent or industrial design right thereafter referred to as "patent rights" in carrying out his contract, and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights (including any amounts properly payable by the Contractor to any of its sub-contractors pursuant to any similar covenant of indemnity given by the Contractor to any sub-contractor), in respect of anything the model, plan or design of which shall have been provided by or on behalf of His Majesty, but this indemnity shall apply to this contract only.

(b) Save and except as set forth in sub-section (a) of this section, the Contractor shall indemnify His Majesty against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent right, and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights in carrying out this contract.
(c) Before making any payments with respect to any patent rights, the Contractor shall supply to the Minister a statement showing all payments and claims for payment by way of royalties or otherwise which the Contractor or any of its sub-contractors will or may be obligated to make or proposes to make to the owner or holder of any patent rights in connection with this contract, and the basis thereof and the parties to whom the same are payable, and shall from time to time promptly advise the Minister of any and all claims or arrangements made or proposed, which would or might result in further or different payments being made by the Contractor or any of its sub-contractors by way of royalties or otherwise as aforesaid.

(d) If and when the Minister shall so direct, the Contractor shall make no payment by way of royalties or otherwise with respect to any patent rights referred to in any statement furnished by the Contractor as provided in sub-section (c) of this section except with the consent of the Minister and subject to such conditions as the Minister may impose and from end after the giving of any such direction by the Minister, His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against any action, claim or proceeding for infringement of the patent rights covered by such direction or for non-payment of royalties or other payments in respect thereof.

22. SANITATION

The Contractor shall comply with, and the work shall be carried on subject to all regulations made by any lawful authority and applicable to said work, and all orders given by the Indian Agent with respect to sanitation or preservation of health on the work. The Contractor shall make adequate arrangements, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for the medical and sanitary supervision of all his employees.

23. INDIAN AGENT'S MARKS

The Contractor shall protect, and shall not remove or destroy, or permit to be removed or destroyed, the stakes, buoys and other marks placed on or about the said work by the Indian Agent or his assistants, and shall furnish the necessary assistance to correct or replace any stake, buoy or mark which through any cause may have been removed or destroyed.

24. NOTICES

Any notice, order, direction or other communication given to the Contractor under any of the provisions of this contract shall be sufficiently given if delivered to the Contractor personally, or left for him or left at the Contractor's office, or mailed at any post office to the Contractor or foreman addressed to the address mentioned in the contract, or to the Contractor's last known place of business or residence.

25. PROGRESS MEASUREMENTS AND CERTIFICATES NOT BINDING

The progress measurements and progress certificates shall not in any respect be taken as binding upon the Indian Agent or as final measurements or as fixing final amounts; they are to be subject to the revision of the Indian Agent in making up his final certificate, and they shall not in any respect be taken as an acceptance of the work or as a release of the Contractor from responsibility in respect thereof.
26. PROTECTION OF WORK

The Contract and all information issued in connection therewith are confidential and their use must be strictly confined to the work and to the purpose of the contract; and particulars contained therein; and other matter issued in connection therewith, must not be disclosed to unauthorized persons.

The Contractor shall at all times take and cause to be taken all reasonable measures, for the protection of the work against espionage and sabotage, and on the order of the Minister shall dispense with the services of any person employed in, about or upon the work or cause the same to be dispensed with. The Minister shall at all times through such agent as he may see fit be entitled to maintain on or about the premises where the work or any part thereof is being carried on such police or other protective force as in the opinion of the Minister may be advisable.

27. CANADIAN WORK AND MATERIALS

To the full extent that the same are procurable, only Canadian labour, parts and materials (unless otherwise agreed by the Minister) shall be used in connection with the work.

27a. EMPLOYMENT OF EX-SERVICE MEN

In engaging labour for the work contemplated by this contract, either from the National Employment Service or from Trade Unions with which the contractor has collective agreements, the contractor shall specify that preference shall be given to competent and available ex-service men.

The contractor shall maintain and keep available for inspection by the Minister a record of the names and addresses of ex-service men employed, together with a record of the steps taken to implement this requirement.

28. SALARIES

The salaries payable to engineers, superintendents, draftsmen and foremen shall only be such as shall be approved by the Minister.

29. TERMINATION

(a) Notwithstanding anything in this contract contained the Minister may, by giving notice to the Contractor, terminate the contract (save and except the provisions of this section and of Section 31 of these general conditions) as regards all or any part or parts of the work or works not heretofore completed. Upon such notice being given, the Contractor shall cease work (including the procuring of materials for the fulfilment of the contract) in accordance with and to the extent specified in such notice but shall proceed with all reasonable speed to complete such part or parts (if any) of the work or works as are by the terms of such notice required to be completed. He shall also proceed with all reasonable speed to complete up to such time and/or stage as may be specified in the notice any part or parts of the work or works as required by such notice. The Minister may, at any time, or from time to time give one or more additional notices with respect to any or all parts of the work which remain to be completed after the giving of any previous notice or notices.

(b) All work completed by the Contractor under or pursuant to the provisions of the contract before or after the giving of any notice, subject to acceptance by His Majesty in accordance with the provisions of the contract, shall be paid for on the basis provided in the agreement (the Contractor being allowed such fraction of his
stipulated fee as shall be proportionate to the amount of the work (therefore completed) and the Contractor shall be entitled to be reimbursed the actual cost to the contractor of work not completed under or pursuant to the provisions of this contract and/or any notice given pursuant thereto, plus a fair and reasonable profit in respect of same done thereon, provided that no reimbursement shall be made for materials which have been or may be rejected after inspection as not complying with the terms and conditions of this contract and the specifications.

(c) In the event that the Contractor and the Minister are unable to agree upon the amount in respect of which the Contractor is entitled to be reimbursed as aforesaid, the matter shall be referred to the Exchequer Court.

(d) Whenever practicable the Contractor shall procure materials required for the performance of the contract on terms that will enable it to terminate any contracts entered into by the Contractor for materials and terms similar in effect to those herein provided for in respect to termination by the Minister and the giving of a notice or notices as aforesaid; and generally the Contractor shall co-operate with His Majesty and the Minister and do everything reasonably within its power at all times to minimize and reduce the amount of His Majesty's obligations under the provisions of this section.

(e) Upon reimbursement being made to the Contractor as herein provided, title to the materials and/or work in progress in respect of which such reimbursement is made shall pass to and vest in His Majesty (the Contractor hereby agreeing to execute and deliver all requisite instruments by way of further assurance) and such materials and/or work so procured shall be delivered to the order of the Minister, but the materials thus taken over will in no case be in excess of what would have been required for performing the contract in full if no notice had been given under the provisions hereof.

(f) If it is established to the satisfaction of the Minister by the Contractor that by reason of any action taken by the Minister or under the provisions of this section exceptional hardship has resulted to the Contractor then the Minister may, notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, in his absolute discretion grant such allowance (not to include in any case, however, any allowance or compensation for loss of profit) to the Contractor as, in the opinion of the Minister is warranted by the circumstances.

(g) Any action, decision or determination by the Minister under the provisions of this section shall be final and binding upon the Contractor.

(h) The Contractor shall have no claim for damages, compensation lost of profit, allowance or otherwise by reason of or directly or indirectly arising out of any action taken or notice given by the Minister under or pursuant to the provisions of this section except as and to the extent in this section expressly provided.

(i) The right of termination and of giving notice hereinbefore provided shall be in addition to and not in substitution for any other right possessed by His Majesty and/or the Minister.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are one hundred and five (105) Indian children of school age, for whom educational facilities are required, at Hay Lakes, Fort Vermilion Indian Agency, in the Province of Alberta;

THAT funds are available in Vote 216, 1948-49, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, for the establishment of a residential school for these children.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that a residential school be established at Hay Lakes, Fort Vermilion Indian Agency in the Province of Alberta, in accordance with the provisions of Section 9 (b) of the Indian Act, Chapter 98, 1927, to be known as the "Hay Lakes Indian Residential School".

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.
Ottawa, 30th March, 1949.

Dear Mr. Neary:

I am pleased to advise that all the building material and food supplies, except plumbing and heating, have been trucked to Hay Lakes before break up.

As spring was unusually early, trucks were racing before the road ban was put into effect. In fact, the road ban was enforced the day following the completion of the transportation.

This week, Mr. Geo. L. Villeneuve, Treasury Representative, called at McLennan, examined and certified First Progress Payment Claim which he will forward to Ottawa this weekend.

Both Mr. Villeneuve and myself went to High Prairie and had all accounts signed by Mr. G. S. Lapp, Indian Superintendent at High Prairie, whom you kindly recommended to be Clerk of Works.

Since break up, it is now impossible for me to get in touch with Hay Lakes. When truckers were hauling materials and supplies to Hay Lakes, I was able to correspond with the superintendent of construction there but since trucking has been completed and the roads leading from Grimshaw highway to Hay Lakes have become impassable, there is no means of communication with Hay Lakes. I think that a two way wireless station between McLennan and Hay Lakes should be installed; however, I shall discuss this matter fully with you in another letter shortly.

Kindest regards and say hello for me to your neighbour,

Yours sincerely,

Rev. L. Beuglet

Mr. B.F. Neary,
Supt. of Education,
Indian Affairs' Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Neary,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your telegram of the 16th instant in which you explained that the proposed rate for Mr. Verret is considered excessive. Instead of replying you by wire, I thought that it would be more satisfactory to do so by letter, as this would permit me to explain more fully the reason why this salary is being paid to Mr. Verret.

Mr. Verret is about 45 years old and has some ten years of experience in construction work; he is a full-fledged civil engineer, who came to McLennan last year upon the request of the McLennan Chamber of Commerce and the Oblate Fathers of the Diocese of Grouard. The construction of fireproof buildings is his specialty, but he can ably handle any type of construction work. Having heard of his arrival in the Peace River Country, some Edmonton construction firms have offered him contracts which he declined to accept owing to the fact that he had already promised to handle the Hay Lakes project. Lately perusing an architectural review, I was agreeably surprised to see his "ad" and a picture of the Hotel Windsor which he built at Rouyn, Quebec. I take great pleasure in enclosing same for your information.

Usually a Contractor is paid a fee equal to 10% of the net cost of all materials and labour; in the case of Hay Lakes the estimated amount of $175,000.00 has been appropriated for this construction; therefore, if the contract had been given in the usual way, a fee of $17,500.00 would have been paid to the Contractor. Mr. Verret has agreed to erect the residential school at Hay Lakes for the amount of $8,000.00, payable $500.00 monthly beginning February 1st 1949 to April 1st 1950 and the balance $500.00 on April 1st 1950, including board at the Missionary's shack at Hay Lakes. I believe that Mr. Verret's charges are fair and just and that the Corporation Episcopale C.R.de Grouard has made a considerable saving by subletting this contract to Mr. Verret. I may say that it was not possible for us to find another Contractor who would agree to accept this contract for a lower fee, on account of Hay Lakes being so isolated and distant from the railroad and other conveniences.

Trusting that the foregoing explanations will justify the rate of salary which we have agreed to pay to Mr. Mr. Verret. In conclusion, I may say that you can rest assured that it is our intention not to exceed the amount of $175,000.00 that was appropriated for the construction of this school, if we can at all help it.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Progress Claim No. 1 $59,918.78

The audit of Progress Claim No. 1 has been completed by the undersigned at the Corporation's office at McLennan, Alberta and the report thereon follows:

Payrolls and Payroll Charges

The Contractor has submitted accounts for the salary paid to the Superintendent, A. Verret, C.E. who has been retained for this contract at an agreed price of $8000.00 payable in monthly payments of $550.00 with board provided. Although official approval has not been received from the Department, the rate would seem quite reasonable in view of the engineering and designing work that the Corporation had to provide. It is doubtful that a competent Superintendent could be employed at a lower salary in an isolated area such as Hay Lakes.

Vacation Pay and Unemployment Insurance would not apply to this employee by reason of the existing agreement on the remuneration. The employee has been covered under the Workmen's Compensation Act at the rate of 4%.

Materials and Supplies

The Corporation has purchased a good portion of the materials that will be required. This was done in order to effect delivery to the project before the roads became impassable as a result of the spring thaw.

Supplier's invoices have been checked in considerable detail for calculations and extensions. Delivery of the goods was established to a satisfactory degree by examining freight bills and the trucker's invoices which in turn were signed by a representative of the Corporation at Hay Lakes.

On Invoice #56 from McLennan Lumber and Hardware the following items should not have been charged to the contract and will require an adjustment on a subsequent claim.
The total of Invoices 59 and 60 from H. Thompson, Grimshaw, has been incorrectly extended as $23,668.66 instead of $27,568.66. The undercharge of $4000.00 will be adjusted on a future claim.

Several suppliers' invoices show that the goods are shipped prepaid. However it has been determined that payment of freight is later borne by the purchaser i.e., the Corporation.

General

While a good deal of materials have been delivered to the site of the building, the Corporation has informed the writer that work has progressed only to the point of erecting temporary building to provide shelter for the materials.

The Corporation has been helpful in every way to lend its' assistance in the compilation of the records and accounts.

The charges submitted in this claim are in accordance with the provisions of the contract. No fee or profit has been derived by the contractor for the services performed and materials delivered.

Subject to the above remarks, Progress Claim No. 1 has been certified.

J. L. Villeneuve,
Treasury Auditor.

Dear Father Beuglet:

By now, you will have received, or will shortly receive, a cheque for $99,918.78 as Progress Payment No. 1 on the construction of the Hay Lakes Residential School.

I would suggest that this application be clarified by explaining in it clearly the terms under which Mr. Verret is working. As I understand it from your letter of April 19, these terms are as follows:

1. He has agreed to erect a residential school at Hay Lakes for an amount not to exceed $8,000.

2. This amount is to be paid to him in instalments of $500.00 monthly, commencing 1 February, 1949, to April 1, 1950, with the balance of $300.00 to be paid to him on April 1, 1950.

3. He is also to be provided with board at the Mission at Hay Lakes.

Dear Mr. Neary:

As you are no doubt aware, Hay Lakes is completely isolated from the outside world. Before break up, when truckers were hauling material and supplies to Hay Lakes, I was able to correspond with the Superintendent of the construction there, but since the trucking has been completed and the roads leading from the Grimsby highway to Hay Lakes have become impassable, there is no means of communication with Hay Lakes.

I think that a two-way wireless station between McLennan and Hay Lakes is an absolute necessity. I discussed this matter with Mr. G. L. Villeneuve, Treasury Representative, and with Mr. G. S. Lapp, Indian Superintendent at High Prairie, who also believe that this installation is imperative.

Enclosed herewith letter to the Department of Transport, and application for licence to install and operate radio station at Hay Lakes and McLennan, as well as application for approval.

Mr. Secker, Manager, Radio Supply Co., Ltd., Edmonton, whom I consulted in the matter, explained to me that both stations could be installed at an approximate cost of $800.00.

It is felt that this expenditure would be amply justified by the numerous airlane trips saved, if this two-way radio is installed.

Yours very truly,

Rev. L. Beuglet.

P.S. The Department of Transport may be inclined to think that there is an R.C.C.S. at Fort Vermillion and may suggest that Hay Lakes be connected with Fort Vermillion. However, Mr. Secker of Radio Supply Co., Edmonton, who is versed in the locations of the R.C.C.S. throughout this territory, informs me that he has no knowledge of a R.C.C.S. located at Fort Vermillion. At any rate, it would be far more expedient to be able to communicate direct from McLennan to Hay Lakes, and this is what you should advocate.
La Corp. Episc.C.R. de Grouard,

Gentlemen:

We are submitting herewith completed application forms covering two proposed radio installations, to be operated in Northern Alberta. We would like to draw your attention to the following in respect to the location and purpose of the proposed stations.

Hay Lake: This point is located in the extreme north of the Province of Alberta. An Indian School is being built at this location under the sponsorship of the Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch. A camp has been established there and a number of men are being employed; to expedite delivery of materials, a radio station connected with our headquarters at McLennan would save much time and a great deal of money. In case of emergency such as sickness or accident during construction, the radio would be of inestimable value. There is no existing means of communication in this remote area, the country being mountainous in most part, there are no established roads and if help was needed it would perhaps take days before outside help would be obtained. Inspection of a map would indicate the remote geographical location. When the school is established the radio station would be continued as a means to order necessary supplies and to serve in cases of emergency. I would point out that the radio station which has been in operation at the Indian School at Wainman for a number of years has already been directly responsible for saving several lives.

McLennan: This is our headquarters from which point the establishment of the Indian School at Hay Lake will be directed and through which all supplies are ordered. It is from here that we would direct help in cases of emergency. McLennan is connected with the outside by Telegraph, but there is no means of communication between McLennan and Hay Lake. On looking at a map you will see that McLennan is approximately 200 miles south of the Indian School Location.

For the distance involved we believe that a frequency between 4 megacycles and 5 megacycles would be most suitable, as this has been proven by other stations operating in the north, operating over similar distances.

Yours truly,

La Corporation Episcopale C.R. de Grouard
McLennan, Alta.

Rev. L. Beuglet.
