Dear Father Plourde:

A letter which you wrote to Major MacKay, Director of the Indian Affairs Branch dated May 9th, dealing with the New Residential School at Hay Lakes, Alberta, was passed to this Branch for study and comment, previously to your visit here where the matter was discussed between us.

The point raised by Bishop Routhier has been studied by our Chief Architect and he advised me that the roof of the building can be raised, thereby removing the need for dormer windows, without increasing the cost, and that the boilers selected for installation have sufficient capacity to heat the increased cubical content satisfactorily.

I am pleased that the Bishop's suggestion can be adapted without adding to the cost, since the overall expenditure set out in the Agreement between the Roman Catholic Episcopal Corporation of Grouard and the Crown, is the limit to which the Department is prepared to go.

The Director of Indian Affairs has concurred in the revision to the structure, and it will therefore be in order for you to advise Bishop Routhier accordingly.

Yours very truly,

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Referring to your marginal notation dated the 12th instant on Major MacKay's memorandum to you of May 11th to which was attached a copy of Father Plourde's letter to the Director of Indian Affairs, you are advised as follows:

Our former Minister, Mr. McKinnon had arranged with Bishop Routhier to provide Departmental funds for the construction of this school by the Oblate Fathers from drawings prepared by our own architects.

A reasonable cost was estimated to be $150,000.00 with a contingency allowance of 10%. The total thus reached of $165,000.00 was the limit to which Departmental contribution was to have been made.

Authority from Council, the Agreement with La Corporation Episcopal Catholique Romaine de Grouard, and the payment of all accounts during construction, were responsibilities assumed by Indian Affairs.

Discussing the matter with Col. Neary this morning, it was learned that authority from Council to Indian Affairs permits the expenditure of Departmental funds to the amount of $175,000.00.

Dealing with the request of Bishop Routhier received from Father Plourde the matter of eliminating dormers, and as an alternative increasing the height of the upper floor slightly so that the roof overhang will be about the top of second storey windows, raises no structural problem, and since the heating equipment as designed has sufficient capacity to take care of the additional volume that will be produced in the building, the change should make no difference to the total cost.

Major MacKay was contacted by telephone this morning and stated to your Chief Architect, that he was satisfied with any arrangement that was considered advisable by this Branch. Father Plourde was also advised by telephone that this Branch would raise no objection to the structural revision suggested and that following written confirmation from you, he could advise Bishop Routhier of our approval.

HEATING SYSTEM

The building shall be heated by a two pipe low pressure steam heating system from a separate boiler room. The heating system has not been shown on the floor plans but Sheet M-1 shows an outline of the Boiler Room layout with sizes and capacities of the various items of equipment given.

The 5" steam main serving the School shall be run in an underground concrete trench between the Boiler Room and the School in accordance with the detail. The main shall be graded down from the Boiler Room 1/4" in 10'-0" to the point of entry in the laundry of the School. At this point the main shall be dripped through a float and thermostatic trap and shall rise to the ceiling of the Basement where distribution will be made.

Adjacent to the point of entry, provide and locate in pit as shown one horizontal condensation return pump to receive all the building returns. This unit will pump the condensate to the receiver in the Boiler Room which in turn will pump the condensate back to the boilers.

It is contemplated that supply and return mains will be carried near the Basement ceiling to serve the radiation in the building. Basement radiators shall be wall hung and located approximately 1'-6" above basement floor. The returns from the basement radiators will be run under the radiators on the wall and thence to the pump and receiver in the laundry. Sections of this wet return may be run in an 8" x 8" concrete trench below basement floor where necessary. Such trenches to be provided with checkerplate removable covers.

Mains and branch mains to be covered with 4-ply 1" thick asbestos air cell sectional pipe covering. Returns need not be covered.

Cast iron radiators to be used throughout. Each radiator to be fitted with thermostatic radiator trap and packless valve.

DAMP PROOFING

1. Exterior walls of all main building, except Boiler Room to be given two coats of an asphaltum waterproofing compound, on exterior face from bottom of footings to within 6" below finished grade before backfilling is done. Waterproofing compound to be applied as per manufacturers directions.

CONCRETE FLOORS

1. Under floor fill - After backfilling has become well consolidated lay a 4" bed of thoroughly compacted clean, coarse gravel or cinders.

2. Floor curing - Concrete floors shall be cured and protected by covering with waterproof paper, well lapped and covered with sand. This is to be left for a period of at least two weeks.

CARPENTRY

1. Structural lumber to be of sizes as shown on drawings and to be common structural grade Western Spruce or B.C. fir.

2. Waterproof and vapour proof building paper shall be laid between all sub and finished floors. 12 lb saturated felt paper shall be applied to exterior wall surface before asbestos shingles are laid and same to apply on roof boarding before laying of Asphalt Shingles. A double layer of paper shall be applied around all door and window openings.

INSULATION

1. Insulation to be applied to all exterior stud walls and over entire ceiling areas. Insulation to be rock wool, or other type of insulating batts 3" having vapour proof backing and to be securely stapled to studs or joists.

WALL AND CEILING FINISH

1. Apply to walls and ceilings 3/8" Gypsum wall board applied with close butted joints. Where necessary cut in between ceiling joists headers to provide nailing at ends of boards.

WOOD LOUVRES

1. Install wood louvres as shown on drawings and provide same with 14 wire mesh screening on backs.

STAIRS

1. Interior stairs to have 1-1/8" birch treads, 7/8" risers and 1-3/4" stringers well blocked, glued and wedged in best manner. Newels, balustrades and handrails to be of stock design.

2. Exterior stairs to be as above with intermediate carriage.

3. Interior landings to be of as typical floor construction. Exterior landings to be 1-1/8" T & G flooring.

REFRIGERATORS

1. Line walls, floor and ceilings with two 2" layers of insulating cork not less than 2" thick over a layer of vapour proof paper. Plaster walls and ceiling with 1/2" Keene's cement trowelled smooth. Lay 2" floor of concrete. Provide standard size and type refrigerator doors.
ROOFING

1. Lay over flat roofs tar and gravel roofing with materials in accord with specification of manufacturer.

SHEET METAL

1. Sheet metal for flashings, gravel stops and the covering of cupula to be 26 gauge galvanized iron or 16 oz roofing copper.
HEATING SYSTEM

The building shall be heated by a two pipe low pressure steam heating system from a separate boiler room. The heating system has not been shown on the floor plans but Sheet M-1 shows an outline of the Boiler Room layout with sizes and capacities of the various items of equipment given.

The 5" steam main serving the School shall be run in an underground concrete trench between the Boiler Room and the School in accordance with the detail. The main shall be graded down from the Boiler Room 1/4" in 10'-0" to the point of entry in the laundry of the School. At this point the main shall be dripped through a float and thermostatic trap and shall rise to the ceiling of the basement where distribution will be made.

Adjacent to the point of entry, provide and locate in pit as shown one horizontal condensation return pump to receive all the building returns. This unit will pump the condensate to the receiver in the Boiler Room which in turn will pump the condensate back to the boilers.

It is contemplated that supply and return mains will be carried near the Basement ceiling to serve the radiators in the building. Basement radiators should be wall hung and located approximately 1'-6" above basement floor. The returns from the basement radiators to be run under the radiators on the wall and thence to the pump and receiver in the laundry. A portion of this wet return may be run in an 8" x 8" concrete trench below basement floor where necessary. Such trenches to be provided with checkerplate removable covers.

Mains and branch mains to be covered with 4-ply 1" thick asbestos air cell sectional pipe covering. Returns need not be covered.

Cast iron radiators to be used throughout. Each radiator to be fitted with thermostatic radiator trap and packless valve.

Ends of steam mains to be dripped through float and thermostatic traps complete with valve, strainer, unions, etc., at all necessary points.

Progress Claim No. 2 - $36,983.32

The audit of Progress Claim No. 2 has been completed at the Corporation's office at McLennan, Alberta and the report thereon follows:

Payrolls and Payroll charges:

The salary contract with Superintendent A. Verret has been referred to the Department for approval.

The payroll extracts submitted herewith have not been compiled correctly although the hours worked, rate of pay, gross earnings and board deductions correspond to the Corporation's records.

Vacation Pay, Unemployment Insurance and Workmen's Compensation charges have been calculated on the net earnings resulting in the following payroll undercharges:

| Item          | Amount charged | Correct charge | Undercharge |
|---------------|----------------|----------------|-------------|
| Wages         | $1,766.30      | $2,179.30      | $412.99     |
| Vacation Pay  | $24.13         | $31.99         | $7.86       |
| U.I. Con'tri. | $11.85         | $12.00         | $.15        |
| W.C.B.        | $72.42         | $86.45         | $14.03      |
| Totals        | $1,894.70      | $2,311.83      | $417.13     |

Owing to fact that the contractor is located at some 300 miles from Edmonton and is not conveniently accessible, the claim has been approved, in the interim, subject to have the necessary adjustments incorporated in a future claim.

The payroll for the period from April 11 - 16 shows an error of $2.00 in the extensions of net earnings for Ned. Collins, R. Collins and G. Giroux, all of which are to be taken into account on a future claim.
The hours of work have exceeded the minimum hour regulations of the Province in most instances and it is possible that the Corporation may be required to pay overtime on any excess over 48 hours per week. This matter will be investigated.

Board deductions and value of free board applicable to employees on the project have been credited to board expenses on the summary of invoices for materials.

Materials

Adjustments have been made in the present claim for items that should not have been charged on Claim No. 1 Invoice #58 amounting to $12.45 and on Invoice #68 amounting to $17.35. An undercharge of $4,000 on Claim No. 1, Invoices #58 and #60 has also been adjusted.

The following discrepancies have been noted on invoices included in the present claim.

| Shows | Should be | Underpaid |
|-------|-----------|-----------|
| Inv. #17 - A. H. Esch & Co. | $24.15 | $24.35 | $.20 |
| Charged |
| Inv. #33 - Henry Thompson | $4374.42 | $5374.42 | $1000.00 |
| Overcharge |
| Inv. #39 - Imperial Oil | $364.35 | $358.95 | $.50 |
| Inv. #46 - McLennan Lumber | $965.20 | $963.68 | $.52 |

Inv. #40 covers bank charges amounting to $55.25 which the Corporation has claimed in order to finance the large amount of expenditures which were required to obtain the materials necessary and effect delivery of same before the spring thaw. As the Corporation receives no fee whatever, it has submitted these bank charges which would appear to be justified under the circumstances.

Insurance

The Corporation has obtained adequate Insurance coverage and produced the Policies for examination. It was noted, however, that the Policies had not been made payable jointly to the Corporation and the Crown. The matter was immediately attended to and a copy of the Policies will be filed with the Indian Affairs Branch in due course.

General

The Corporation has continued to give all the information and assistance that it was able to provide in the maintenance of records and filing of claims. As the school is to be erected at some 300 miles away from the Corporation's Headquarters and no regular mail service exists, it is most difficult to obtain any data on the work in progress.
For this reason the Corporation has been unable to provide a breakdown of the expenditures incurred to date. Other than temporary buildings and shelters, little work and material have actually gone into the construction of the school.

Subject to the foregoing remarks and adjustments, Progress Claim No. 2 has been certified.

Dear Mr. Neary,

With further reference to our application for approval of purchase and installation of a two-way radio between Hay Lakes School and McLennan, I wish to reiterate that this installation is an absolute necessity. There is neither mail nor telegraph service at Hay Lakes, which is located some eighty miles off the highway between Grimshaw and Upper Hay Post, as shown on attached map; moreover, the trail between Hay Lakes and Upper Hay Post is impassable during the Summer months.

Lately one of our Lay Brothers who is foreman at Hay Lakes was seriously injured and it was only after eight days of great suffering that news of the accident reached McLennan; a plane was chartered to pick up the patient and bring him to the hospital at McLennan; at present it is hard to say if this most capable brother will ever be able to return to work at Hay Lakes. A good percentage of the hired men at Hay Lakes are married and their wives are most eager to get in touch with their husbands for various reasons. Imagine a man being away from home for many months and his wife being unable to get in touch with her husband. A woman has just stepped into my office, asking me how she could get in touch with her husband working at Hay Lakes; she explained to me that she must undergo an operation, but the doctor would not perform this operation before she obtains the consent of her husband. The only truck which is being used on the job at Hay Lakes broke down lately; trucking was suspended for two weeks; had there existed a means of communication between Hay Lakes and McLennan, the necessary repairs could have been forwarded immediately. The lady who did the cooking at Hay Lakes was forced to return home on account of ill health and news of her departure reached us only after eight days had elapsed; a hired man was taken from the building project to do the cooking, until such times as another lady cook could be found. Had there been a means of communication in existence between the two points, this situation could have been remedied immediately.

The above mentioned incidents amply justify the installation of these two-way radios; these are available at Edmonton and can be installed without delay. It is hoped that you now see your way clear to have this special purchase approved by the Department and thus avoid further delays in the construction of the school at Hay Lakes. An early reply will be greatly appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. L. Beuglet, O.M.I.

Dear Major McKay:

I have received some complaints in connection with an Indian residential school which is being built at Hay Lake. My information is that the Indians in the Fort Vermilion Superintendency, who would be served by this school, would much prefer to have two day schools built - one at the Post at the Upper Hay River Settlement, where I am told there are about 200 Indians, and the other at the Settlement at Hay Lake. I am told that these schools could be built at these points out of local logs at a cost of $7,000.00 to $8,000.00 per room as has been done at other points in Alberta.

I understand that the projected residential school is to be at the Mission at Gun River, some eight miles from the present Indian Settlement and that far from the Highway, which makes it very inaccessible. I am also told that there are 136 children of school age and that the residential school as projected will only accommodate 80.

Would you be good enough to give me any other information you have in connection with the school situation of the Fort Vermilion Superintendency and the reasons why a residential school is being put up there in place of day schools, and particularly why it is being placed in such an apparently awkward spot.

One other complaint I have had is that children with T.B. are being admitted to the residential school at Fort Vermilion and thereby the disease is being spread.

Dear Sir:

On your recent trip to McLennan, you interviewed Father Beuglet regarding a Day School at Upper Hay River and the amount and site of land that should be given to the Residential School at Hay Lakes.

As soon as your request for information was passed on to me by Father Beuglet, I contacted Father Arbet who is the missionary in charge of the Indians at Hay Lakes and Upper Hay River. Father Arbet writes that the Indians at Upper Hay River desire a Residential School like that at Hay Lakes, as they are still obliged to go trapping in the woods and would probably be forced to bring their wives and children along.

I personally have never taken a stand on this question and so long as the Catholic Education of these children is provided, I shall take none. I have understood that decision had been taken for a Day School at Upper Hay River and as a Residential School had been granted to Hay Lakes, I did not see the need of a Residential School at Hay River. There are undoubtedly distinct advantages in both forms of schools and inasmuch as I was concerned, I thought a Residential School at Hay Lakes would suffice for both groups of Indians. However, as the Indian Department seemed decided on giving Upper Hay River a Day School, I did not in any way contradict this decision. As the Indian Department is convinced that the children will attend regularly the Day School and a good Catholic Teacher is assured, I shall be satisfied. I hesitate somewhat in believing that there will be a regular attendance, the experience of the day school at Whitefish Lake does not make it any more reassuring for Upper Hay River. At Whitefish Lake, the Indians are forced to go down into the bush to trap from time to time and take their families along. It may well happen that gradually the Indian population will understand that it is to its advantage in seeing that the children obtain a proper education and make the necessary sacrifices. Let us hope so.

Re: Land for Indian School at Hay Lakes

I am including a rough sketch of the land that Father Arbet would like to have attached to the Residential School. Three sections of land would be required near the extreme south east corner of the Reserve just outside of the Reserve. Or this land, approximately 1/3 of which Father Arbet tells me that Mr. Schmidt, former Superintendent of Reserves, had advised him to obtain two sections, but Mr. Brown, the surveyor of the land, told him it would be better to obtain three sections, although only two sections could be properly used. I am sorry that I have not got the legal description of these three sections of land. This might be obtained through Mr. Knapp, the agent at Fort Vermilion.

The audit of Progress Claim No. 3 has been completed at the Corporation's office at McLennan, Alberta, and the report thereon follows:

Payroll and Payroll Charges

The salary contract with Superintendent Verret has been approved by the Department and charges included in the present claim are in accordance therewith.

Vacation Pay

The Corporation has obtained permission in writing from the Board of Industrial Relations to pay Vacation Pay by cash at termination of employment rather than by stamps. The charges incurred have been set up as allowed charges and will be allowed on the claim upon liquidation by the Contractor.

Unemployment Insurance

Upon personal inquiries made at the local office of the Commission, along with Father Beuglet, the Corporation being a charitable organization and deriving no profit from the contract, is not required to insure employees under this Act. Accordingly all charges previously claimed have been cancelled and adjusted.

Public Liability and Property Damage Insurance

The Corporation has secured an owner's protective liability policy with the Globe Indemnity Co. of Canada (Policy No. 47441) with $5,000 and $10,000 coverage effective April 6, 1949, at the rate of .042% of the employees payrolls.

The audit of Progress Claim No. 5 has been completed at the Corporation's office at McLennan, Alberta, and the report thereon follows:

Payroll and Payroll Charges

The salary contract with Superintendent Verret has been approved by the Department and charges included in the present claim are in accordance therewith.

Vacation Pay

The Corporation has obtained permission in writing from the Board of Industrial Relations to pay Vacation Pay by cash at termination of employment rather than by stamps. The charges incurred have been set up as accrued charges and will be allowed on the claim upon liquidation by the Contractor.

Unemployment Insurance

Upon personal inquiries made at the local office of the Commission, along with Father Beuglet, the Corporation being a charitable organization and deriving no profit from the contract, is not required to insure employees under this Act. Accordingly all charges previously claimed have been cancelled and adjusted.

Public Liability and Property Damage Insurance

The Corporation has secured an owner's protective liability policy with the Globe Indemnity Co. of Canada (Policy No. 47441) with $5,000 and $10,000 coverage effective April 6, 1949, at the rate of .042% of the employees payrolls.

Hay Lakes Indian Residential School.

We have received a copy of Mr. Indian Superintendent Walker's letter of April 19 concerning medical services at Hay Lakes. We have also noted Mr. Walker's comments with regard to the construction of an Indian Residential School at that point.

As you are aware, the services of the Provincial School Inspector were employed to make an educational survey of this area. In his report he recommended the establishment of a residential school at Hay Lakes and in having the school erected, it is felt we are following his advice. His report reads in part as follows:

"With these four classrooms and other necessary teaching rooms this area should be serviced with boarding facilities for the pupils as it does not appear possible to operate a day school, or a number of day schools in the area. The dormitory space required will be the usual for this number of children. Included in the dormitory should be rooms where the children may work or play if it is not sufficiently close to the school. The usual plumbing fixtures should be installed as well as facilities for giving a steam bath."

Would you please draw the above to the attention of Mr. Walker. I would also suggest that you discuss his comments with Dr. Stone as it is felt that we are following professional advice in having a residential school erected at Hay Lakes.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

THAT these quotations have been reviewed by the officers of the Lands & Development Services Branch and they recommend the acceptance of the quotation of Medland Machinery, Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba, in an amount of Five Thousand, Four Hundred and Sixty Nine Dollars ($5,469.00).

THAT it is essential that this heavy equipment be purchased at the earliest possible date in order to take advantage of low rates for winter freight.

The undersigned therefore recommends that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of Medland Machinery, Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba, to supply an electric lighting plant on which they have tendered, at a price of Five Thousand, Four Hundred and Sixty Nine Dollars ($5,469.00), which due to contingencies will involve an expenditure of approximately Six Thousand Dollars ($6,000.00).

Respectfully submitted,

PP/ST
Minister of Mines and Resources.

770-5 (E1)

Ottawa, 14 December, 1949.

AIR MAIL

January 6th, 1950.

Rev. L. Beuglet, O.M.I.,
Bishop's Residence,
McLennan, Alberta.

Dear Father Beuglet:

Re: Hay Lakes Residential School

With reference to the requisitions forwarded for equipment for the above school, we require further information regarding the following.

(1) Sisters' Dormitory (Page 2)

Please let me know why you request 100 enamel water basins and 12 water pitchers.

(2) Visitor's Suite (Page 4)

Under this heading there is a request for dining room furniture. Why do you consider this necessary when both the male members of the staff and the Sisters will each have dining rooms.

(3) Dairy (Page 7)

Under this heading there is a request for one frigidaire for milk. We would like to have the catalogue number of some firm that manufactures the type of equipment which you require. This information is necessary in order to have the order placed by the Departmental Purchasing Agent.
(4) Laundry (Page 7)

Similar information should be supplied with reference to the following items appearing under the heading "Laundry":

2 tub washers 40 lbs. electric motor
1 Beatty washer 15 lbs. (110 volts DC)
1 Extractor 22" diameter
2 Farm Cookers 60 gals.
6 Vacuum Clothes Washers
6 Wash tubs 25" x 10"
2 Copper wash boilers 22" x 13"

(5) Bakery (Page 8)

We should also have catalogue numbers and more detailed information regarding the following items listed under the heading "Bakery":

1 Bread oven 6' x 6' x 3' deep
1 Dough mixer (150 people) 110 Volts DC
1 Bread slicer
48 Bread Cooking pans 14" x 10" x 4" deep

The other items on the requisitions which we usually supply are being ordered by the Departmental Purchasing Agent.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
December 23, 1949.
